An '''Adequate Public Facilities Ordinance''', '''APFO''', or '''Concurrency Regulation''' is a legislative method to tie public infrastructure to growth for a region.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cost of Concurrency: A Legal and Empirical Analysis of Adequate Public|author =Dustin Cole Read|page=40}}</ref>
APFOs take into account the availability of infrastructure. They can affect growth, but are considered separate from growth controls such as building [[moratorium (law)|moratoria]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Managing Community Growth|author =Eric D. Kelly|page=60}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Gazette|title=Gardner says moratorium will not hurt building industry|date=10 January 2008|author =Sherry Greenfield}}</ref>
[[File:Ramapo NY View.JPG|right|thumb|View of Ramapo, New York]] [[Ramapo, New York]]; [[Petaluma, California]]; and [[Boulder, Colorado]] were some of the early adopters of this tool in America.<ref>{{cite book|title=Urban Development: The Logic Of Making Plans|author = Lewis D. Hopkins|page=138}}</ref> The state of Florida uses the term "concurrency" in its growth management act.<ref>{{cite book|title=Planning and Urban Design Standards|author1=American Planning Association |author2=Frederick R. Steiner |author3=Kent Butler |page=377}}</ref>
APFO regulations take into affect some or all of a jurisdiction's infrastructure requirements, including:<ref>{{cite book|title=Adequate Public Facilities Ordinances and Transportation Management|author =S. Mark White|page=17}}</ref> *[[Transportation planning|Transportation]] *School facilities *Water supply *Water treatment *Roads
Other elements include: *CIP – Capitol Improvement Programs *Service Level Standards
==Scope== APFO regulations are typically applied to a jurisdiction which has legislative control of a given area. In America, this can be at a state, county, or city level. A conflict can occur when APFO regulations differ in scope between jurisdictions where there is shared funding and legislative authority (such as a city located inside a county that funds schools).<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Gazette|title= Calvert County finds northern school populations inadequate Multiple schools closed to future district development|author =Sara Newman|date=1 January 2015}}</ref> While APFOs are intended to mitigate infrastructure shortcomings for a particular area, the mitigation may apply to areas offsite of the development project.<ref>{{cite book|title=Driveway Regulation Practices|author =Kristine Williams|page=58}}</ref> APFO regulations usually apply to individual projects on a case-by-case basis.<ref>{{cite book|title=Land Use Law|author =Daniel R. Mandelker}}</ref>
==Criticism== [[File:Parris Glendening speaking, September 2006.jpg|right|thumb|Maryland Governor Parris Glendening advocating Smart Growth in 2006]] Traditional opponents of APFO legislation include industries affected by moratoria or fees, including [[Real estate broker|realtors]], [[Real estate development|developers]], and some [[Smart Growth]] advocates.<ref>{{cite web|title=The National Center for Smart Growth|url=http://smartgrowth.umd.edu/APFOMaryland.html|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref> Home costs for some locations that have enacted APFO have experienced increases in housing prices affecting affordable housing, in conjunction with positive effects of relief from school capacity shortcomings.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cost of Concurrency: A Legal and Empirical Analysis of Adequate Public|author =Dustin Cole Read|page=123}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.municode.com/library/fl/collier_county/codes/land_development_code?nodeId=CH6INIMADPUFARE_6.02.00ADPUFARE An example of a Florida APFO regulation] *[[Dolan v. City of Tigard]] – property rights
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Ekistics|Ecistics]] * [[Activity centre]] * [[Context theory]] * [[Exclusionary zoning]] * [[Form-based codes]] * [[Inclusionary zoning]] * [[Mixed use development]] * [[New urbanism]] {{col-2}} * [[Non-conforming use]] * [[Planning permission]] * [[Principles of Intelligent Urbanism]] * [[Reverse sensitivity]] * [[Spot zoning]] * [[Statutory planning]] * [[NIMBY]] {{col-end}}

The '''Batallón Único de Inteligencia y Contrainteligencia''' ({{lang-en|Battalion of Intelligence and Counterintelligence}}) of the [[Colombian National Army]]. The BINCI has also been referred to as the "Charry Solano battalion," after its original chief, Brigadier General Ricardo Charry Solano.
It has also been known as the '''Twentieth Brigade''' or '''Brigade XX'''.<ref name="NSA1">{{cite news|title=The Truth about Triple-A |publisher=National Security Archives |date=2007-07-01 |author=Michael Evans}}</ref><ref name="HRW3">{{cite book|title=Colombia's Killer Networks: Glossary |publisher=Human Rights Watch |year=1996}}</ref>
==Controversy==
===Triple A=== {{main|Alianza Americana Anticomunista}} During the years of its operation, the BINCI was considered the Colombian National Army's primary [[counter-intelligence]] unit and under direct operational control of the E-2 Army intelligence directorate in [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]].
A [[declassified]] 1979 report from the United States Embassy in Bogotá, published in 2007 by the [[National Security Archive]], mentioned that there was a plan for the BINCI to form a [[paramilitary]] operation under the guise of the [[Alianza Americana Anticomunista]] (AAA). The report describes the goal of the formation of the AAA as "to create the impression that the American Anti-communist Alliance has established itself in Colombia and is preparing to take violent action against local [[communism|communists]]." The BINCI, acting as the AAA, has been linked to the December 1978 [[Bombing#Delivery|bombing]] of the [[Colombian Communist Party]] Headquarters, the bombing of the Communist Party newspaper ''Voz Proletaria''. It has also been accused of engaging in other [[kidnapping]]s, bombings and [[assassination]]s against [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] targets and guerrilla detainees.<ref name="NSA1" /><ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|title=U.S. cable ties Colombian military to rights abuses |date=2007-07-01 |publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
===Forced Disappearance=== On August 30, 1987, Nydia Erika Bautista de Arellana was kidnapped by a group of undercover operatives identified as part of Brigade XX.<ref name="Amnesty1">{{cite book|title=Colombia: Human Rights and USA Military Aid to Colombia III |publisher=Amnesty International |date=February 2002}}</ref> Nydia Erika was 30 years old and had previously been detained due to her student activism and membership in the [[19th of April Movement|Movimiento 19 de Abril]] ({{lang-en|19th of April Movement}}) (M-19) guerrilla group. On September 12, 1987, her body was found, showing signs that she had been shot once in the head [[Execution-style murder|execution style]]. On July 9, 1995, Colombia's Procurator-Delegate for Human Rights, Hernando Valencia Villa, announced the conclusions of a disciplinary investigation into the 1987 "[[forced disappearance|disappearance]]", [[torture]] and [[murder]] of Nydia Erika Bautista and called for Brigadier General Álvaro Hernán Velandia Hurtado and an army sergeant to be expelled from the armed forces. It was found that the then commander of Brigade XX for which the "Charry Solano" Army Battalion was attached, was fully aware of the capture, disappearance, torture and murder of Nydia Erika Bautista by men under his command and that he had had the "duty, power and opportunity to prevent this serious crime from being committed".<ref name="Amnesty2">{{cite book|title=Colombia: Selected Cases for Campaigning Against Human Rights Violations |publisher=Amnesty International |date=March 1998}}</ref><ref name="Amnesty3">{{cite news|title=Day of the "disappeared" 2004 |publisher=Amnesty International |year=2004 |url=http://news.amnesty.org/pages/2004dofd_americas |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811165734/http://news.amnesty.org/pages/2004dofd_americas |archivedate=2007-08-11 |df= }}</ref>
===Assaults=== On February 27, 1998, the BINCI was implicated by Colombian government investigators in the murders of human rights workers; lawyer Jesús María Valle, president of the "Héctor Abad Gómez" Permanent Committee for Human Rights in [[Antioquia Department|Antioquia]] and human rights lawyer Eduardo Umaña. In May 1998 the Twentieth Brigade assaulted the offices of Justicia y Paz ({{lang-en|Justice and Peace}}) where they were reported to have ransacked the offices and forced nuns and human rights workers to their knees and placed guns to their heads.<ref>Human Rights Watch interviews with government investigators, Santafé de Bogotá, May 7–8, 1998.</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1999 |publisher=House of Representatives |date=September 17, 1998}}</ref><ref name="HRW1">{{cite book|title=War Without Quarter: Colombia and International Humanitarian Law |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=October 1998}}</ref>
On May 19, 1998, the BINCI was disbanded pending a reorganization, in part due to their participation in human rights abuses.<ref name="HRW1" /><ref name="HRW2">{{cite book|title=HRW: World Report 1999: Colombia: Human Rights Developments |publisher=Human Rights Watch |year=1999}}</ref>
==See also== *[[History of Colombia]] *[[Kidnappings in Colombia]] *[[Military of Colombia]] *[[Paramilitarism in Colombia]] *[[Politics of Colombia]]
==References== <references />

{{Refimprove|date=August 2007}} A '''bridge loan''' is a type of short-term [[loan]], typically taken out for a period of 2 weeks to 3 years pending the arrangement of larger or longer-term [[financing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bridgeloan.asp|title=Investopedia Definition: Bridge Loan |publisher=Investopedia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://financial-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/bridge+loan|title=Financial Dictionary: Bridge Loan}}</ref> It is usually called a '''bridging loan''' in the United Kingdom, also known as a "caveat loan," and also known in some applications as a '''swing loan.''' In South African usage, the term '''bridging finance''' is more common, but is used in a more restricted sense than is common elsewhere.
A bridge loan is interim financing for an individual or business until permanent financing or the next stage of financing is obtained. Money from the new financing is generally used to "take out" (i.e. to pay back) the bridge loan, as well as other [[Capital expenditure|capitalization]] needs.
Bridge loans are typically more expensive than conventional financing, to compensate for the additional risk. Bridge loans typically have a higher interest rate, [[Point (mortgage)|points]] (points are essentially fees, 1 point equals 1% of loan amount), and other costs that are amortized over a shorter period, and various fees and other "sweeteners" (such as equity participation by the lender in some loans). The lender also may require [[cross-collateralization]] and a lower [[loan-to-value ratio]]. On the other hand, they are typically arranged quickly with relatively little documentation.
==Real estate==
Bridge loans are often used for commercial real estate purchases to quickly close on a property, retrieve real estate from foreclosure, or take advantage of a short-term opportunity in order to secure long-term financing.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/eca790f4-6663-11e3-aa10-00144feabdc0 Guide to bridging loans] ''[[Financial Times]]''. 3 February 2014. Retrieved 27 November 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.finance-monthly.com/2018/06/what-is-a-bridging-loan/ What Is a Bridging Loan?] ''Finance Monthly Magazine''. 21 June 2018. Retrieved 27 November 2018.</ref> Bridge loans on a property are typically paid back when the property is sold, refinanced with a traditional lender, the borrower's creditworthiness improves, the property is improved or completed, or there is a specific improvement or change that allows a permanent or subsequent round of mortgage financing to occur. The timing issue may arise from project phases with different cash needs and risk profiles as much as ability to secure funding.
A bridge loan is similar to and overlaps with a [[hard money loan]]. Both are non-standard loans obtained due to short-term or unusual circumstances. The difference is that hard money refers to the lending source, usually an individual, investment pool, or private company that is not a bank in the business of making high-risk, high-interest loans, whereas a bridge loan is a short-term loan that "bridges the gap" between longer-term loans.
===Characteristics===
For typical terms of up to 12 months, 2–4 points may be charged. <ref>{{cite web|title=Bridge Loans - Terms of bridge loans|url=http://izmcreditservices.net/bridge-loans/}}</ref> Loan-to-value (LTV) ratios generally do not exceed 65% for commercial properties, or 80% for residential properties, based on appraised value.
A bridge loan may be closed, meaning it is available for a predetermined time frame, or open in that there is no fixed payoff date (although there may be a required payoff after a certain time).<ref name="Telegraph">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/borrowing/mortgages/8839404/Bridging-loans-increase-45pc-due-to-new-landlord-appetite.html Bridging loans increase 45pc due to new landlord appetite] ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''. 21 October 2011. Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref>
A first charge bridging loan is generally available at a higher LTV than a second charge bridging loan due to the lower level of risk involved, many UK lenders will steer clear of second charge lending altogether.
Lower LTVs may also attract lower rates, again representing the lower level of underwriting risk, although front-end fees, lenders legal fees, and valuation payments may remain fixed.
===Examples===
*A bridge loan is often obtained by developers to carry a project while permit approval is sought. Because there is no guarantee the project will happen, the loan might be at a high interest rate and from a specialized lending source that will accept the risk. Once the project is fully entitled, it becomes eligible for loans from more conventional sources that are at lower-interest, for a longer term, and in a greater amount. A [[construction loan]] would then be obtained to take out the bridge loan and fund completion of the project.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.mortgagemagazine.com.au/detail_article.cfm?articleID=1010| title=Short-term loans| date=November 2006| accessdate=2007-03-09| publisher=Mortgage Professionals Australia| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620170631/http://www.mortgagemagazine.com.au/detail_article.cfm?articleID=1010| archivedate=2007-06-20| df=}}</ref> *A consumer is purchasing a new residence and plans to make a down payment with the proceeds from the sale of a currently owned home. The currently owned home will not close until after the close of the new residence. A bridge loan allows the buyer to take equity out of the current home and use it as down payment on the new residence, with the expectation that the current home will close within a short time frame and the bridge loan will be repaid. *A bridging loan can be used by a business to ensure continued smooth operation during a time when for example one senior partner wishes to leave whilst another wishes to continue the business. The bridging loan could be made based on the value of the company premises allowing funds to be raised via other sources for example a management buy in. *A property may be offered at a discount if the purchaser can complete quickly with the discount offsetting the costs of the short term bridging loan used to complete. In auction property purchases where the purchaser has only 14–28 days to complete long term lending such as a buy to let mortgage may not be viable in that time frame whereas a bridging loan would be.
==Corporate finance==
Bridge loans are used in [[venture capital]] and other [[corporate finance]] for several purposes: *To inject small amounts of cash to carry a company so that it does not run out of cash between successive major private equity financings<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/5a4c68fe-e573-11e7-97e2-916d4fbac0da Private equity turns to early loans to boost returns] ''[[Financial Times]].'' 1 January 2018. Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref> *To carry distressed companies while searching for an acquirer or larger investor (in which case the lender often obtains a substantial equity position in connection with the loan) *As a final debt financing to carry the company through the immediate period before an [[initial public offering]] or an acquisition.
==South Africa==
In [[Law of South Africa|South African law]] [[real estate|immovable property]] is transferred via a system of registration in public registries known as [[Recorder of deeds|Deeds Offices]].<ref>Badenhorst, PJ et al. Silberberg & Schoeman's The Law of Property. Fourth Edition. Butterwoths. 2003</ref><ref>Deeds Registries Act, 47 of 1937</ref> Given the delays resulting from the transfer process, many participants in property transactions require access to funds which will otherwise only become available on the day that the transaction is registered in the relevant Deeds Office.
Bridging finance companies provide finance that creates a bridge between the participant's immediate [[cash flow]] requirement and the eventual entitlement to funds on registration in the Deeds Office. Bridging finance is typically not provided by [[bank]]s.
Various forms of bridging finance are available, depending on the participant in the property transaction that requires finance. Sellers of fixed property can bridge sales proceeds, [[estate agent]]s bridge estate agents' commission, and [[Mortgage law|mortgagors]] bridge the proceeds of further or switch bonds. Bridging finance is also available to settle outstanding property taxes or municipal accounts or to pay [[transfer tax|transfer duties]].
==United Kingdom==
===History===
Short term finance similar to modern bridging loans was available in the UK as early as the 1960s, but usually only through high street banks and building societies to known customers.<ref name="History 1">[https://www.kisbridgingloans.co.uk/all-about-bridging/a-brief-history-of-bridging-loans/ History of bridging loans and how bridging has evolved] KIS Finance. 26 September 2018. Retrieved 27 November 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.mortgagefinancegazette.com/features/brief-history-of-the-bridging-finance-sector-04-08-2016/ Brief history of the bridging finance sector] ''Mortgage Finance Gazette''. 4 August 2016. Retrieved 27 November 2018.</ref> The bridging loan market remained small into the millennium, with a limited number of lenders.<ref name="History 1"/>
Bridging loans became increasingly popular in the UK after the [[great recession|2008–2009 global recession]], with gross lending more than doubling from £0.8 billion in the year to March 2011 to £2.2 billion in the year to June 2014.<ref name="West One">August 2014 Bridging Index. West One. Retrieved on 1 Jun 2015 from [https://archive.fo/20130707070216/http://www.westoneloans.co.uk/publications/bridging-index/ http://www.westoneloans.co.uk/publications/bridging-index/]</ref>{{rs?|date=February 2017}} This coincided with a marked decline in mainstream [[mortgage loan|mortgage]] lending in the same period, as [[bank]]s and [[building society|building societies]] grew more reluctant to grant home loans.<ref name="MSM guide">[http://www.moneysupermarket.com/loans/bridging-loans-guide/ Bridging loans guide]. Money Supermarket. Accessed on 1 Jun 2015.</ref><ref name="Telegraph"/>
The overall value of the residential loan amounts outstanding in Q1 2016 was £1,304.5billion, an increase of 1.0% compared with Q4 2015 and an increase of 3.4% over the past four quarters.<ref name="WW">{{cite web|title=MLAR statistics|url=https://www.fca.org.uk/your-fca/documents/mlar-statistics-june-2016-commentary|website=www.fca.org|accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref>
As the popularity of bridging loans increased, so too did the controversy around them. In 2011, the [[Financial Services Authority]] (FSA) warned homebuyers against using bridging loans as substitutes for ordinary mortgages, expressing fears that some mortgage brokers might be misrepresenting their suitability.<ref>Powley, T. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4ceef468-16be-11e1-bc1d-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3bXZJNdLj Borrowers warned on bridging loans]. Financial Times. 25 Nov 2011</ref>
Since 2011, the bridging market has been monitored by the West One Bridging Index, and has seen a consistent increase in popularity and prevalence coinciding with a consistent drop in average monthly interest rates.<ref name="West One" />{{rs?|date=February 2017}}
===Usage===
In the United Kingdom, bridging loans are used in both business and [[real estate]]. In the former, they are typically used to free [[equity (finance)|equity]] in order to boost [[cash flow]]. In the latter, they are used by home-movers to ‘break’ property chains by providing a short-term source of finance when there is a delay between sale and completion dates, by buyers bidding on property at [[auction]], and by landlords and property developers to secure renovation finance for quick sale<ref name="MSM guide" /> or to refurbish a property that is considered uninhabitable prior to obtaining ordinary mortgage finance.
===Characteristics===
Bridging loans can be secured as a first or second charge against real property, including [[commercial property|commercial real estate]], buy-to-let property, dilapidated property and land or building plots. Loan terms typically run up to 18 months, with compound interest charged monthly; as such, they are often more expensive than other types of secured home loan.<ref name="MSM guide" />
Bridging loans are defined as either ‘opened’ or ‘closed’. A loan is closed if the borrower has a clear and credible repayment plan or exit strategy in place, such as the sale of the loan [[security (finance)|security]] or longer-term finance.<ref>Haill, O. [http://www.ftadviser.com/2013/04/18/mortgages/mortgage-products/types-of-bridging-loan-and-how-they-compare-to-alternatives-cUlvzccwX01VKZ4xCiaCLO/article.html Types of bridging loan and how they compare to alternatives]. FT Adviser. Apr 18 2013.</ref> Open bridging loans are riskier to both the borrower and [[creditor]] due to the greater likelihood of [[default (finance)|default]].
===Regulation=== {{Update|section|date=November 2018}}
Bridging loans secured by first charge against a property in which the borrower or a close family member will reside are considered regulated mortgage contracts, and are therefore regulated by the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] (FCA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fca.org.uk/firms/financial-services-products/mortgages/bridging-loans |title=Archived Document |accessdate=2015-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150602015847/http://www.fca.org.uk/firms/financial-services-products/mortgages/bridging-loans |archivedate=2015-06-02 |df= }}</ref> Bridging loans sold to landlords and property developers are generally not regulated; however, if the occupant of the rental property against which the loan is secured is or will be a close family member of the borrower, FCA regulation will still apply.<ref>[https://fshandbook.info/FS/html/FCA/PERG/4/4#D319 Financial Conduct Authority Handbook PERG 4.4.1]. Accessed on 1 Jun 2015.</ref>
An exception currently exists in the case of mixed-use properties, where the borrower or a close relative will occupy less than 40% of the property. In March 2016, however, the UK will be forced to bring its existing legislation in line with that of Europe, under the pan-European Mortgage Credit Directive (MCD). As the MCD does not recognise usage thresholds when defining a regulated contract, it is currently unclear whether the ‘40% rule’ will continue to apply.<ref>[http://www.economicvoice.com/how-will-the-mortgage-credit-directive-affect-mixed-use-properties/ How will the Mortgage Credit Directive affect mixed-use properties?] Economic Voice. 27 Mar 2015.</ref>
==See also== *[[Hard money lenders]] *[[Commercial lender (US)|Commercial lenders]] *[[Non-conforming loan]] *[[Gap financing]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox political party |name = British Democratic Party |logo = |colorcode = {{British Democratic Party (2013)/meta/color}} |leader = |president = |chairman = James Lewthwaite |general_secretary = |first_secretary = |secretary_general = |presidium = |secretary = |spokesperson = |foundation = {{Start date|9 February 2013}} |ideology = [[Ultranationalism]]
[[Euroscepticism]]
[[Souverainism]]
[[Right-wing populism]]
[[British unionism]] |headquarters = [[Loughborough|Loughborough, Leicestershire]] |international = |website = http://www.britishdemocrats.org.uk/ |country = United Kingdom |deputy chairman = |position = [[Far-right]] | colours = {{colour box|Blue}}{{colour box|Red}}{{colour box|White}} }} The '''British Democratic Party''', commonly known as the '''British Democrats''', is a British [[far-right]] political party. It was launched in 2013 in a village hall in [[Leicestershire]] by a ten-member steering committee which included former members of several political parties including the [[British National Party]] (BNP), Democratic Nationalists, [[Freedom Party (United Kingdom)|Freedom Party]] and [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP). The party's inaugural president was [[Andrew Brons]], a then [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP).{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2013/02/neo-nazi-former-bnp-members-launch-new-far-right-party|title=Neo-Nazi former BNP members launch new far-right party |work=[[New Statesman]]|author=Collins, Matthew|date=8 February 2013|accessdate=8 February 2013}} Brons had been a member of the BNP and a leading member of the [[National Front (United Kingdom)|National Front]] (NF). The steering committee included a number of others with a history of membership in [[fascism|fascist]] and [[neo-Nazi]] groups,Ray Mount, [http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/archive/british-democratic-party-launches-and-promises-it-will-belong-to-its-members "British Democratic Party launches and promises it will belong to its members"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703024415/http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/archive/british-democratic-party-launches-and-promises-it-will-belong-to-its-members |date=3 July 2013 }}, ''Searchlight'', 1 March 2013 who believed that the BNP had been corrupted and watered-down. ==History== Brons resigned from the BNP in October 2012, after a failed campaign to unseat [[Nick Griffin]] as leader of the party in 2011. A number of other disillusioned BNP members have joined him, including Kevin Scott, founder and director of [[Civil Liberty (UK)|Civil Liberty]], who is acting as the interim chairman of the BDP, and who used to be a party organiser for the British National Party in the North East. Other prominent members of the party include: * [[Adrian Davies (barrister)|Adrian Davies]], a longstanding critic of Griffin and a former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] member and former [[Freedom Party (United Kingdom)|Freedom Party]] chairman, who wrote the party's constitution and registered the party name, * [[John Bean]], the former editor of the British National Party magazine ''Identity'', * James Lewthwaite, a former [[Bradford Metropolitan District Council|Bradford councillor]], who along with others established the Democratic Nationalists in 2010, and who stood for the Democratic Nationalists,{{cite web|title=James Lewthwaite|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/news_elections/general_election_2010/constituencies/145.bradford_south/candidates/2540._james_lewthwaite/|newspaper=[[Telegraph and Argus]]|accessdate=22 May 2013}} * Julian Leppert, who had been a councillor in [[London Borough of Redbridge]] and [[London mayoral election, 2004|stood for London Mayor]] for the British National Party,{{cite web|url=http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/archive/british-democratic-party-launches-and-promises-it-will-belong-to-its-members|title=British Democratic Party launches and promises it will belong to its members|work=[[Searchlight (magazine)|Searchlight]]|author=Mount, Ray|date=1 March 2013|accessdate=16 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703024415/http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/archive/british-democratic-party-launches-and-promises-it-will-belong-to-its-members|archivedate=3 July 2013|df=}}
- {{cite web|url=http://britishdemocraticparty.org/successful-british-democratic-party-launch-30-05-13/|title=Successful British Democratic Party London Launch 30.05.13|accessdate=16 June 2013|publisher=British Democratic Party|date=2 June 2013}} and * Andrew Moffat, a former UKIP and BNP[http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/elections/general_election_2010/constituencies/123.bognor_regis___littlehampton/candidates/3294._andrew_moffat/ "General Election: Andrew Moffat Candidate for: Bognor Regis & Littlehampton"], ''The Argus'' parliamentary candidate who worked with Andrew Brons in the European Parliament[http://www.radixjournal.com/altright-archive/altright-archive/main/blogs/euro-centric/the-launch-of-the-bdp "The launch of the BDP"], ''Radix'' {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706054144/http://www.radixjournal.com/altright-archive/altright-archive/main/blogs/euro-centric/the-launch-of-the-bdp# |date=2017-07-06 }} Nick Lowles, of [[Hope not Hate]], believes the party will be a serious threat to the BNP. "The BDP brings together all of the hardcore Holocaust deniers and racists that have walked away from the BNP over the last two to three years, plus those previously, who could not stomach the party’s image changes.... They and the BNP already have a mutual hatred of each other and neither party will stop until they’ve killed the other one off. The gloves will be off and it will be toxic". Mathew Collins, also of Hope not Hate, predicted that the party would espouse policies of [[scientific racism]] and [[Holocaust denial]], ideas from which the BNP, under Griffin, distanced themselves. Andrew Brons has been the leader of the British Democratic Party since its foundation on 9 February 2013.Electoral Commission: [http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP1765 Registration summary] == Policies == The British Democrats support putting the reintroduction of the death penalty to a referendum/people's vote. They are committed to "ending all immigration" and wish to repeal laws that they perceive as mandating preferential treatment for immigrants and ethnic minorities.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishdemocraticparty.org.uk/|title=British Democratic Party| accessdate=2 February 2016}} The party wishes to withdraw the UK from the [[European Union]], citing the cost and what it sees as a lack of democracy within EU institutions. ==Electoral performance== The party fielded three candidates in the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2013|2013 English County Council elections]]:{{cite news|url=http://efp.org.uk/election-preview-2013/|newspaper=Heritage and Destiny|title=Election preview 2013|date=5 April 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}}
- ''[[Newsnight]]'' (10 April 2013). [[BBC]]. two in north [[Leicestershire County Council|Leicestershire]] and one in [[Borough of Pendle|Pendle]], Lancashire. In Leicestershire, the party polled 215 votes (7.4%) in [[Coalville]] and 206 votes (7.4%) in [[Loughborough]] South,{{cite web|url=http://www.leics.gov.uk/index/your_council/local_democracy/aboutthecountycouncil/useyourvote/election_results/election_2013.htm|title=Election Results Leicestershire County Council 2013|publisher=Leicestershire County Council|date=3 May 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013}} while in Lancashire it polled 133 (4.0%).[http://www3.lancashire.gov.uk/elections/results/2013/divres.asp?div=1301&p=e Election Results 2013], Lancashire County Council. In a by-election for the Loughborough Hastings ward of [[Charnwood Borough Council]] on 24 October 2013, the British Democrats polled 85 votes (9.4%).[http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Double-success-Labour-Loughborough-Shepshed/story-19988645-detail/story.html "Double success for Labour in Loughborough and Shepshed by-elections"], ''Leicester Mercury'', 25 October 2013 The party did not contest the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|May 2014 European Parliament election]], but stood candidates in the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2014|local elections]]: two in [[Bradford City Council|Bradford]],Bradford Metropolitan District Council, [http://www.bradford.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/7B8D9610-7B8E-4E5D-9433-FC24BB098917/0/StatementOfPersonsNominated.pdf Statement of persons nominated] one in [[Leeds City Council election, 2014|Leeds]],Leeds {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502013632/http://www.leeds.gov.uk/docs/Statement%20of%20Persons%20Nominated.pdf |date=2 May 2014 }} three in [[Newcastle City Council|Newcastle upon Statement of persons nominated] and one in the [[London Borough of Redbridge]].London Borough of Redbridge, Hainault ward accessible from '''Bruno Vogel''' (1898–1987) was a German pacifist and writer.
==Biography== Bruno Vogel was born on September 29, 1898 in [[Leipzig]].<ref name="glr">Raimund Wolfert, 'Get to Know Bruno Vogel', in ''[[The Gay & Lesbian Review Worldwide]]'', Jan-Feb 2010, pp. 29-31</ref> He spent his childhood in [[Bohemia]].<ref name="glr"/> In 1916, he fought in the [[First World War]], first on the border of the [[Austro-Hungarian empire]], then in the [[Baltic region|Baltic]], and in [[Flanders]] by 1917.<ref name="glr"/>
In 1922, he founded the gay group [[Gemeinschaft Wir]] ("We the Community") under the aegis of [[Magnus Hirschfeld]].<ref name="glr"/> It was the local chapter in [[Leipzig]] of the [[Scientific-Humanitarian Committee]], one of the largest gay groups in Germany from 1896 to 1933.<ref name="glbtq">[http://www.glbtq.com/literature/vogel_b.html glbtq] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140549/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/vogel_b.html |date=June 29, 2011 }}</ref> In the mid-20s, after his parents put him out on the streets for being gay, he moved to [[Berlin]], and he founded the [[Revolutionary Pacifists Group]] with [[Kurt Hiller]].<ref name="glr"/> In 1928, he became a member of the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]], but soon left.<ref name="glr"/>
In 1938, he moved to [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] with [[Otto Bohlmann]].<ref name="glr"/><ref name="glbtq"/> From 1942 to 1944, he worked in the [[South African Army]].<ref name="glr"/> Later, he wrote for ''Forward'', ''Common Sense'' and ''[[Jewish Affairs]]''.<ref name="glr"/> In 1953, he moved to [[London]], from where he was involved in the anti-[[apartheid]] movement.<ref name="glr"/>
He died on April 5, 1987 in London.<ref name="glr"/> His novel ''Alf'' from 1929 was first translated into English in 1992.
In August 2012 someone put Bruno Vogel's unpublished works, such as the novel ''Mashango'' and the short stories he had collected under the title ''Slegs vir Blankes'' ("Only for Whites"), on the Internet anonymously.<ref name="brunovogel.co.uk/index.htm">https://web.archive.org/web/20150103220511/http://www.brunovogel.co.uk/index.htm</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Es lebe der Krieg!'' ("Long Live War!") [1924] *''Ein Gulasch und andere Skizzen'' ("A Goulash and other Sketches") (1928) *''Alf'' (1929) [English translation by Samuel B. Johnson, GMP Publishers Ltd., 1992] *''Mashango'' *''Slegs vir Blankes'' ("Only for Whites")
==Further reading== * Raimund Wolfert: ''Nirgendwo daheim. Das bewegte Leben des Bruno Vogel''. Leipzig: Leipziger Universitätsverlag 2012.

'''Carbon leakage''' occurs when there is an increase in [[carbon dioxide]] emissions in one country as a result of an [[emissions reduction]] by a second country with a strict climate policy.<ref>{{citation |title=Emissions Loophole Stays Open in E.U. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/19/business/energy-environment/emissions-loophole-stays-open-in-eu.html |accessdate=1 April 2015 |author=Andrés Cala |publisher=The New York Times |date=18 November 2014}}</ref>
Carbon leakage may occur for a number of reasons: * if the emissions policy of a country raises local costs, then another country with a more relaxed policy may have a trading advantage. If demand for these goods remains the same, production may move offshore to the cheaper country with lower standards, and global emissions will not be reduced. * if environmental policies in one country add a premium to certain fuels or commodities, then the demand may decline and their price may fall. Countries that do not place a premium on those items may then take up the demand and use the same supply, negating any benefit.
There is no consensus over the magnitude of long-term leakage effects.<ref name=goldemberg>{{cite book |date=1996 |author=Goldemberg, J. |title=Introduction: scope of the assessment. In: Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor=J.P. Bruce. |publisher=This version: Printed by [[Cambridge University Press]], Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. PDF version: IPCC website |format=PDF |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/sar/wg_III/ipcc_sar_wg_III_full_report.pdf |isbn=978-0-521-56854-8 |doi=10.2277/0521568544 |pages=27–28|display-authors=etal|display-editors=etal}}</ref> This is important for the problem of [[climate change]].
Carbon leakage is one type of [[spill-over effect]]. Spill-over effects can be positive or negative;<ref>{{Citation |year=2007 |title=Glossary A-D. In (section): Annex I. In (book): Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor=B. Metz |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |author=IPCC |url=https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg3/ar4-wg3-annex1.pdf |accessdate=2010-04-18|display-editors=etal}}</ref> for example, emission reductions policy might lead to technological developments that aid reductions outside of the policy area.
"Carbon leakage is defined as the increase in {{CO2|link=yes}} emissions outside the countries taking domestic mitigation action divided by the reduction in the emissions of these countries."<ref name=barker>{{Citation |year=2007 |title=11.7.2 Carbon leakage. In (book chapter): Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective. In (book): Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor = B. Metz |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |author=Barker, T. |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-7-2.html |accessdate=2010-04-05|display-authors=etal|display-editors=etal}}</ref> It is expressed as a percentage, and can be greater or less than 100%.
Carbon leakage may occur through changes in trading patterns, and that is sometimes measured as the balance of emissions embodied in trade (BEET).<ref>{{citation |author1=Jiahua Pan |author2=Jonathan Phillips |author3=Ying Chen |title=China’s balance of emissions embodied in trade: approaches to measurement and allocating international responsibility |journal=Oxford Review of Economic Policy |volume=24, Number 2, 2008, pp.354–376}}</ref>
==Coal, oil and "backstop" technologies==
The issue of carbon leakage can be interpreted from the perspective of the reliance of society on coal, oil, and "backstop" (less polluting) technologies, e.g., [[biomass]]. This is based on the theory of nonrenewable resources.<ref name=goldemberg/> The potential emissions from coal, oil and gas is limited by the supply of these nonrenewable resources. To a first approximation, the total emissions from oil and gas is fixed,{{clarify|reason=what does "fixed" mean?|date=April 2015}} and the total load of carbon in the atmosphere is determined by coal usage.
A policy that sets a [[carbon tax]] only in developed countries might lead to leakage of emissions to developing countries. However, a negative leakage (i.e., leakage having the effect of reducing emissions) could also occur due to a lowering in demand and price for oil and gas. This might lead coal-rich countries to use less coal and more oil and gas, thus lowering their emissions.<ref name=goldemberg/> While this is of short-term benefit, it reduces the insurance provided by limiting the consumption of oil and gas. The insurance is against the possibility of delayed arrival of backstop technologies. If the arrival of backstop technologies is delayed, the replacement of coal by oil and gas might have no long-term benefit. If the backstop technology arrives earlier, then the issue of substitution becomes unimportant. In terms of climate policy, the issue of substitution means that long-term leakage needs to be considered, and not just short-term leakage.<ref name=goldemberg/>
== Current schemes == Estimates of leakage rates for action under the [[Kyoto Protocol]] ranged from 5 to 20% as a result of a loss in price competitiveness, but these leakage rates were viewed as being very uncertain.<ref>{{Citation |year=2007 |title=Executive Summary. In (book chapter): Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective. In (book): Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor= B. Metz |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |author=Barker, T. |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html |accessdate=2010-04-05|display-authors=etal|display-editors=etal}}</ref> For energy-intensive industries, the beneficial effects of Annex I actions through technological development were viewed as possibly being substantial. This beneficial effect, however, had not been reliably quantified. On the empirical evidence they assessed, Barker ''et al''. (2007) concluded that the competitive losses of then-current mitigation actions, e.g., the [[EU ETS]], were not significant.
Recent North American emissions schemes such as the [[Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative]] and the [[Western Climate Initiative]] are looking at ways of measuring and equalising the price of energy 'imports' that enter their trading region<ref>[http://www.rggi.org/docs/rggi_workplan_6_14_06.pdf RGGI Imports and Emissions Leakage Working Group]</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{globalize|date=September 2013}} {{Citation style|date=November 2014}} }} {{course assignment | course = Education Program:University College London/MSIN1003 Information World (Autumn 2014) | term = 2014 Q3}} A '''chief learning officer''' ('''CLO''') is the highest-ranking [[corporate officer]] in charge of learning management. CLOs may be experts in corporate or personal training, with degrees in education, instructional design, business or similar fields.
Qualified CLOs should be able to drive the corporate strategy and align the development of people with the business goals of the organization. A full complement of skills, including business analytics, technology, learning theory, performance consulting and scientific inquiry, are important for success.<ref>[http://www.bersin.com/blog/post.aspx?id=de0e7229-d688-4746-8736-5817482885c8 Bersin by Deloitte: Today's World-Class Chief Learning Officer]</ref>
The CLO may report directly to the [[CEO]], but may also report to the Head of [[Human Relations|HR]] or Chief Talent Officer.
==Background== In the 1990s, [[Jack Welch]], then CEO of [[GE]], made Steve Kerr his CLO, making GE the first company to have such an officer.<ref>"Steve Kerr and His Years with Jack Welch at GE", ''Journal of Management Inquiry'', December 2002, 11: 343-350</ref> Kerr also became the CLO and Managing Director for [[Goldman Sachs]]
=== Promotion === In 2012, Emma Cunis, executive director of the [[Chartered Institute of Management Accountants]] spoke at a CLO summit held in [[Mumbai]]. Cunis was part of a panel that discussed the cost of not investing in executive [[Training and development|learning and development]]. She quoted former General Electric CEO Jack Welch to make her case: "The Jack Welch of the future cannot be like me. I spent my entire career in the United States. The next head of General Electric will be someone who spent time in Bombay, in Hong Kong, in Buenos Aires…. We have to send our best and brightest overseas and make sure they have the training that will allow them to be global leaders who will make GE flourish in the future."<ref>[http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/india/article.cfm?articleid=4716 Wharton University: "India Learns the Value of the Chief Learning Officer"]</ref>
==Learning techniques== There are four types of learning techniques that may be employed by CLOs (Elkeles & Phillips, 2007):<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jack, Tamar|first1=Phillips, Elkeles|title=The Chief Learning Officer|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vb8JBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=ko&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> ; Coaching : Coaching refers to the training and development process wherein the CLO will support and train an individual or team in achieving a specific skill, competence, or goal. The individual or team receiving the coaching may be referred to as the coachee(s) (Flaherty, 2010).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Flaherty|first1=James|title=Coaching: Evoking Excellence in Others|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Nfv94keo5cC&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22James+Flaherty%22&hl=ko&sa=X&ei=ObVSVNGaF83xavS5gvAM&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|website=Google e-book|publisher=Elsevier Inc|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> :The higher value for a CLO, relative to coaching, is to create a culture of coaching. All managers should become proficient coaches, and data on personal performance and contribution should be available to them. The more informed they are, the better coaches they can be. ; Engagement : Engagement refers to the process of being psychologically invested in the learning process. It is often seen as an indicator of success in learning and the CLO will often attempt to maximize engagement of students and measure engagement during a variety of different learning tasks in order to rate their effectiveness (Christenson et.al., 2012).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Christenson, Wylie, Reschly|first1=Sandra, Cathy, Amy|title=Handbook of Research on Student Engagement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7LSxRvDF-RgC&printsec=frontcover&hl=ko&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media.|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> :Many CHROs have found the engagement surveys to be less than useful, because: they capture only a point in time, you tend to only find out what's wrong, the cycle time from survey to action is often long enough to make taking action irrelevant. ; Mentoring : Mentoring refers to a personal development relationship in which one more experienced individual will assist a less experienced learning in acquiring a new skill, ability, or competency. This process involves communication and is relationship based. It may be said to include formal transfers of knowledge, social capital, and psychological support (Clutterbuck & Garvey, 2006).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clutterbuck, Garvey|first1=David, Bob|title=Mentoring in Action: A Practical Guide for Managers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w9IO4CgMVREC&pgis=1&redir_esc=y|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> ; Management training : Management training activities are those activities which specifically relate to improving the management of people. CLOs may also be responsible for providing training and measuring success of skills and competencies related to management functions (Bonner, 2000).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bonner|first1=Ded|title=Leading Knowledge Management and Learning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ISWqgaRpaAwC&pgis=1&redir_esc=y|publisher=American Society for Training and Development|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
==Measurement techniques== Measurement techniques refer to how CLOs measure learning outcome success. These may take several forms and can include standardized tests, one-to-one interviews and discussions with individuals receiving learning assistance, surveys and questionnaires, and measured competency at various tasks before and after the learning activity (Rani, 2004; Rauner & Maclean, 2008).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rani|first1=T. Swarupa|title=Educational Measurement and Evaluation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CRt893qk8c4C&printsec=frontcover&hl=ko&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=Discovery Publishing House|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref> The aim of the use of these measurement techniques is to quantify the success of the learning activity. This allows the CLO to adapt learning activities in future to increase the level of successful outcomes (Jonassen et al., 2008).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jonassen, Spector, Driscoll, Merrill, Merrienboer|first1=David, Michael, Marcy, M.David, Jeroen|title=Handbook of Research for Educational Communications and Technology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GgCPAgAAQBAJ&pgis=1&redir_esc=y|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
==Technology used== A wide variety of different technologies may be used by CLOs in order to meet their learning objectives. Popular technologies used include the use of computer software to deliver lessons and tests. Additionally, internet based learning may be used to provide learning at remote locations and enable students to engage with lessons remotely (Iskander, 2008; Facer, 2011).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Iskander|first1=Magued|title=Innovative Techniques in Instruction Technology, E-learning, E-assessment and Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ngQH8S7Zx0gC&pgis=1&redir_esc=y|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media.|accessdate=30 October 2014}}</ref>
==Doctoral Program== The [[University of Pennsylvania]] has their own Doctoral Program under their Graduate School of Education called the PennCLO Executive Doctoral Program. It specially prepares the Chief Learning Officers and other senior-level Human Capital Executives for success in their role as learning and talent development leaders.<ref>[http://www.pennclo.com/ PennCLO: Executive Doctoral Program]</ref>
==CLO Data== There is scant data when it comes to the CLO position, considering that the position has only existed since 1991. In terms of salary, [[Indeed.com]] reports that the average salary is roughly $81,000<ref>[http://www.indeed.com/salary?q1=Chief+Learning+Officer&l1=]</ref> per year, as of May 2015. According to a CLO survey conducted in April 2015,<ref>[http://elearningmind.com/chief-learning-officer/ Chief Learning Officer Industry Survey 2015: Infographic]</ref> roughly 45% of CLOs are female, which is a remarkably strong number for female representation in the c-suite. As a comparison, just 3%<ref>[http://www.strategyand.pwc.com/media/file/Strategyand_The-2013-Chief-Executive-Study.pdf]</ref> of CEOs are female, according to Pricewaterhouse Coopers.
==Role within the C-Suite== The chief learning officer often works alongside the CEO and collaborates on his or her vision for instituting learning and development initiatives throughout the company. Occasionally the CLO will work closely with the [[chief technology officer]], because much of L&D involves technological advancement. The [[chief knowledge officer]] will also assist the CLO in disseminating knowledge for employees to learn and apply. The chief culture officer will assist the CLO with any culture-based programs or initiatives, though most companies do not have a CCO at the moment.
==Publications== <!-- Please keep in alphabetical order --> Academic and practitioner publications dealing exclusively with CLO roles and responsibilities: * ''[[Chief Learning Officer (magazine)|Chief Learning Officer]]''<ref>http://www.clomedia.com/</ref> * ''[[Learning Executive Briefing]]'' <ref>https://www.td.org/Publications/Newsletters/LX-Briefing</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Political Party |name = Christian Heritage New Zealand |logo = [[File:ChristianHeritageNewZealandLogo-New.png]] |colorcode = #0000CC |president = Bill Van Rij, Henk Geerlofs, Nik Gregg (2003–6) |leader = John Allen (1989-1990) [[Graham Capill]] (1990–2003)
[[Ewen McQueen]] (2003–6) |foundation = July 1989 |dissolution = 3 October 2006 |ideology = [[Christian democracy]] |headquarters = |international =|country=New Zealand}} [[File:Christian Politics NZ.svg|right|400px]] The '''Christian Heritage Party of New Zealand''' (CHP, known for a time simply as '''Christian Heritage New Zealand''') was a [[New Zealand]] political party espousing [[Christianity|Christian]] values and conservative views on social policy. Although it never won seats in an election, it came close to doing so in 1996 as part of the Christian Coalition and briefly had a member in [[New Zealand Parliament|Parliament]]. On 3 October 2006, the Party said it would disband to allow "new things to arise in Christian politics in New Zealand". This came after a highly publicised scandal which resulted in its leader, [[Graham Capill]], going to jail for committing sex crimes. == Policies== According to Christian Heritage New Zealand's self-description, the party aimed "to provide [[leadership]] that takes the initiative in building a culture that affirms [[marriage]], strengthens families, and celebrates [[life]] as a precious gift of [[God]]. We believe these are the key issues that need to be addressed if we are to make an impact for the next generation." It described its three key policies as "Affirming Marriage, Building Families and Celebrating Life", i.e. opposition to [[same-sex marriage]] and [[abortion]] and support of [[Law and order (politics)|law and order]]. The party espoused strongly [[Social conservatism|conservative]] views on [[social policy]]. It favoured law changes to strengthen heterosexual [[marriage]] and to prevent [[same-sex marriage]] and [[civil unions]]. The CHP had an [[anti-abortion]] stance, but for most of its existence, the Party supported the re-introduction into New Zealand of [[capital punishment]] (abolished in 1989). Christian Heritage NZ supported restrictions on [[prostitution]], as well as mandatory standards for [[television]] with a view to reducing [[violence]] and [[pornography]]. In [[economic policy]], Christian Heritage espoused moderately [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] views, and stressed that "economic policy cannot be viewed in isolation" from social matters. In [[education]] the Party emphasised parental influence over the [[curriculum]] and parents' rights to choose the school their child attended. The Party supported [[victims' rights]]. CHP supported [[Monarchy in New Zealand|New Zealand's constitutional monarchy]]. In foreign affairs, the party supported New Zealand's alliance with [[Australia]] and a resumption of its alliance with the [[United States]]. From the [[New Zealand general election, 1999]], the CHP supported New Zealand's anti-nuclear policy, whereas beforehand it had endorsed return to the ANZUS alliance, but not necessarily the return of nuclear-armed ships. CHP supported the [[Treaty of Waitangi]] and the work of the [[Waitangi Tribunal]] and urged settlement of [[Treaty of Waitangi claims and settlements|Māori land claims]] and racial reconciliation. Christian Heritage NZ claimed broad-based support from members of various [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denominations and from the [[Roman Catholic Church]], although many of its past members appeared to have held membership of the tiny [[Reformed Churches of New Zealand]], composed largely of conservative [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] Dutch immigrants. The party had long required its members to publicly declare themselves as Christians. Some commentators{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} criticised this rigid [[confessionalism (religion)|confessional]] policy for supposedly limiting the party's base. == History== ===Founding === The [[Christian Heritage Party of Canada]] was part of the inspiration behind the formation of New Zealand's Christian Heritage Party, and other influences also existed. Many of the party's founding members had Dutch ancestry and familiarity with the history of the [[Anti-Revolutionary Party]], which functioned as an influential political party in Netherlands governments between 1888 and 1980, and many of the party's founding members belonged to the [[Reformed Churches of New Zealand]]. Dirk Vanderpyl noted in his book ''Trust and Obey'' (1994) that many Reformed Churches of New Zealand members came from a narrow slice of Netherlands society, centred in [[Zeeland]], [[Veluwe]] and [[Overijssel]]. In those Netherlands provinces, the Staatkundig Gereformeerde Partij (SGP or [[Political Reformed Party]] in English) had existed since 1922, and stood as a model for separatist Reformed fundamentalist political activism. The SGP differs from the Christian Heritage Party in that it restricts its membership to certain Reformed denominations, while Christian Heritage membership stood open to all [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] Christians, although at first many of its office-holders had some association with the Reformed Churches. However, the SGP has only ever existed as a '[[testimonial party]]'. Also inspired by the Christian Heritage Party of Canada, the Christian Heritage Party of New Zealand emerged in 1989 to promote "[[Bible|Biblical]] principles" in politics, although the party's leadership generally claimed that its policies advantaged even non-Christians. Bill van Rij founded the party and became its first President; former National Party candidate John Allen became its initial leader. ===1990 election === The party's first convention took place in 1990 and established the group's structure. In 1991 the party confirmed [[Graham Capill]], a Reformed Churches of New Zealand [[pastor]], as its leader. During the 1990s, some non-Reformed evangelical Christians repeatedly complained{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} that the CHP took too long to transcend this initial base. Eighteen Christian Heritage candidates contested seats in the [[New Zealand general election, 1990|1990 general election]]. The Party did not gain any seats, but did secure over 10,000 votes across the country. In 1992 the party's candidate, Clive Thomson, finished fourth in a [[by-election]] in the electorate of [[Tāmaki (New Zealand electorate)|Tamaki]]. === 1993 election=== In the [[New Zealand general election, 1993|1993 elections]] the Christian Heritage party stood 97 candidates and polled 2.02% of the overall vote, making it easily the largest party outside parliament, a position the party retained in the 1996, 1999 and 2002 general elections. The Christian Heritage Party supported the ultimately successful campaign to change New Zealand's [[electoral system]] from [[Plurality voting system|first-past-the-post]] to [[Mixed member proportional representation|mixed-member proportional]] (MMP). (New Zealand endorsed MMP in 1993 and has used the system in general elections from 1996 onwards.) ===Christian Coalition and the 1996 election === In 1994, the Christian Heritage Party gained new competition when [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]] MP [[Graeme Lee (politician)|Graeme Lee]] formed the [[Christian Democrat Party (New Zealand)|Christian Democrats]] (originally named the "United Progressives"). Lee had originally considered joining Christian Heritage, but eventually declined because of the party's requirement that all members declare themselves Christians. Later, however, Christian Heritage and the Christian Democrats reached an agreement to contest the [[New Zealand general election, 1996|1996 elections]] together. This resulted in the formation of the [[Christian Coalition (New Zealand)|Christian Coalition]], with Capill and Lee as its co-leaders. Lee held the first slot on the group's "[[party list]]", since he already had a seat in Parliament. Shortly before the election, much speculation occurred {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} as to whether the Christian Coalition would reach the "five percent threshold" necessary to gain proportional representation in New Zealand's MMP electoral system. If the party gained more than five percent of the vote, it would gain entitlement to a share of parliamentary seats equivalent to its support, expected to amount to five or six MPs. Although the Coalition polled as high as 6.7% in polls before the election, in the final tally the Coalition won only 4.4% support. ===1997–1999 === In May 1997 the Christian Coalition collapsed, with the two component parties going their separate ways. Debate continues{{Citation needed| date=August 2007}} on the causes of this breakdown. According to the Christian Heritage Party, the Christian Democrats left the alliance; but other accounts disagree (either blaming Christian Heritage or blaming both){{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}. Points of contention included the extent to which the coalition would admit non-Christians who shared compatible views – after the split, the Christian Democrats would conceal the explicitly religious nature of their party, which they eventually renamed "[[Future New Zealand]]". Shortly afterwards, Bill van Rij left Christian Heritage and joined the Christian Democrats, blaming Capill for the collapse of the Coalition. A number of other senior Christian Heritage members, led by a former Deputy Leader, Geoff Hounsell, also resigned or suffered expulsion from the Party: they joined the Christian Democrats following their unsuccessful attempt to have Christian Heritage agree to a merger with the Christian Democrats. Christian Heritage stood [[Ewen McQueen]] as its candidate in the 1998 [[Taranaki-King Country by-election, 1998|Taranaki-King Country by-election]]. McQueen outpolled candidates for the larger [[New Zealand First]] and [[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Green]] parties. Six months before the [[New Zealand general election, 1999|1999 elections]], [[Frank Grover]], leader of the [[New Zealand Liberal Party (1992)|Liberal Party]], a component of [[Alliance (New Zealand political party)|the Alliance]], defected to Christian Heritage, giving it one seat in Parliament. Grover had entered Parliament as an Alliance [[list MP]]. High-profile broadcaster Philip Sherry also joined the Christian Heritage Party in 1999 and stood in the number 2 position on the party list === 1999 election=== In the [[New Zealand general election, 1999|1999 general election]], Christian Heritage gained 2.4% of the vote, well short of the 5% threshold for entering Parliament, although enough to make it easily the largest party outside parliament. ===2002 election === In the [[New Zealand general election, 2002|2002 election]], Christian Heritage had high hopes. It appointed Australian political consultant (now New South Wales assembly MP for the [[Liberal Party of Australia]]) [[David Elliott (politician)|David Elliott]], who is prominent campaigner against [[Republicanism in Australia]], as its campaign-manager. Party strategists hoped that by focusing on a single electorate, [[Wairarapa]], CHP could gain entry to Parliament and bypass the 5% threshold-requirement. However, the result proved disappointing to supporters – the party itself gained only 1.35% of the vote,{{cite web | work = Official Count Results | title = Overall Status |url= http://www.electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2002/partystatus.html |publisher=Electoral Commission |accessdate=7 August 2013}} and its Wairarapa candidate, deputy-leader [[Merepeka Raukawa-Tait]], came third in the Wairarapa poll.{{cite web | work =Official Count Results | title = Wairarapa |url= http://www.electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2002/electorate-56.html |publisher=Electoral Commission |accessdate= 7 August 2013}} Christian Heritage's support defected{{Citation needed| date=August 2007}} to [[United Future New Zealand]], a political party which had formed from the merger of [[Future New Zealand]] (a successor to the Christian Democrats) and [[Peter Dunne]]'s [[United New Zealand]] Party in 2000. [[File:ChristianHeritageNewZealandLogo.png|frame|right|A former Christian Heritage logo]] ===Aftermath of the 2002 election === In the aftermath of the 2002 election, considerable tension existed between the party's central leadership and the Wairarapa branch. People alleged{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} financial mismanagement against both sides, and Raukawa-Tait criticised Graham Capill's leadership of the party. Capill, in turn, criticised Raukawa-Tait, and rebuked her for her comments. Raukawa-Tait and the entire Wairarapa Electorate Committee eventually resigned. Not long after the [[New Zealand general election, 2002|2002 election]] Capill announced his retirement as party leader and took up a job as a police prosecutor. When Capill's retirement came into effect in August 2003, the Party appointed [[Ewen McQueen]] to replace him. The Party also re-affirmed its determination to carry on contesting elections (rather than remove itself from the list of parties and become a [[pressure group|pressure-group]]). In 2003 the party adopted the name "Christian Heritage New Zealand", or CHNZ, replacing the original "Christian Heritage Party", or CHP. In November 2004 Graham Capill resigned from the Party, citing differences of opinion about the Party's direction such as the dropping of capital punishment. === Graham Capill sex scandal === In March 2005, newspapers reported that a "prominent New Zealander" was "punched and left whimpering on the ground" outside the Christchurch High Court, where he was defending sex charges. The papers could not name the man because of a court suppression-order. On 1 April 2005 the court lifted name-suppression and the press revealed the man as Graham Capill. Capill admitted the indecent assault of an eight-year-old girl on four occasions in 2001 and 2002, while he led Christian Heritage. Further charges of rape and [[indecent assault]] against girls aged under 12 (committed during the 1990s) followed. As Capill had strongly condemned "sexual perversion" throughout his political career, the charges had a strong impact both on Capill and on Christian Heritage, which swiftly condemned his conduct. Newspaper-reports described Capill as "a sexual predator". Before sentencing, Capill emailed supporters asking that they pray for a light sentence and claiming the sex with one of the young girls as "consensual".{{Cite news| last = Binning | first = Elizabeth | title = Capill a broken man at the stand | work = [[The New Zealand Herald]] | date = 2005-07-15 | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10335923 | accessdate = 17 August 2011}} === 2005 election and aftermath === In the [[New Zealand general election, 2005|2005 general elections]], Christian Heritage saw its support collapse even further. The party stood only seven candidates, and only won 2,821 votes (out of more than 2 million cast) or 0.2 percent. It appears that much of its support bled over{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} to [[New Zealand National Party|National]], United Future, and the newly formed [[Destiny New Zealand]]. The loss of support to Destiny proved somewhat surprising, since Destiny has its base in a [[Pentecostal]] organisation, the [[Destiny Church (New Zealand)|Destiny Church]], and McQueen himself has Pentecostal affiliations. A campaign organised by the conservative Christian-influenced [[Maxim Institute]] called "New Zealand Votes 2005" may have become a factor in the Party's disappointing performance in the 2005 general election. The Maxim Institute portrayed the campaign as designed to inform voters. However, some commentators saw it as an ultimately successful attempt to persuade Christian voters not to vote for Christian Heritage New Zealand.[http://www.nzarh.org.nz/fundy/thepost016.htm NZarh.org.nz] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060107201753/http://www.nzarh.org.nz/fundy/thepost016.htm |date=7 January 2006 }} After the election, controversy arose when former CHNZ Policy Director Mark Munroe defended Capill in a private email, arguing that his serial paedophile offenses did not fit the "biblical definition of rape". Ewen McQueen and the CHNZ Board pressured Munroe for his resignation, which ultimately occurred. CHNZ detailed the party's submission to Parliament's Electoral Law [[Select Committee (Westminster System)|Select Committee]] in May 2006. The Party urged the reduction of MMP's five per-cent threshold for list party representation without electorate seats, and abolition of MMP's one seat/list representation rule, which allows parties that have an anchoring constituency seat to gain parliamentary representation without having to clear the five-percent threshold. Following a further review of MMP, the reduction of the 5% threshold to 4% and abolition of the one seat/list representation rule was recommended to parliament, which has to date not adopted the suggested changes. === Disbanding and legacy of the party === On 3 October 2006, the Party announced that it would close down following a postal vote in which 97% of its members endorsed the move.{{Citation | url = http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0610/S00018.htm | newspaper = Scoop | title = Christian Heritage NZ Closing Down | place = [[New Zealand|NZ]]}}. Party leader Ewen McQueen said shutting down would allow a new Christian party to form. He blamed Capill's conviction and disgrace for the party's demise.{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=1&ObjectID=10404090 | title= Capill blamed as Christian Heritage closes down | date= 3 October 2006 | work =[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=24 September 2011}} The main legacy of the party is the adoption by New Zealand of the [[mixed-member proportional representation|mixed-member proportional]] representation electoral system, which the party supported. In addition the party was a catalyst for the formation of other niche religious or [[conservative]] political parties in New Zealand such as the [[Christian Democrat Party (New Zealand)|Christian Democrat Party]]. {{update section|date=June 2018}}Although the party has been disbanded, it has continued to appear sporadically in opinion polls as recently as April 2013.{{Citation | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10872574 | newspaper = NZ Herald | title= Labour Rises at Expense of allies | date= 21 March 2013 | place = [[New Zealand|NZ]]}}. ===Electoral results=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
