Фемен | logo = [[File:Femen Logo.svg|200px]] | type = Protest and activist group | founded_date = {{start date and age|2008|4|10|df=yes}} | founder = | location = [[Paris]], France{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/naked-march-in-paris-to-open-new-office-of-femen-feminist-group-a-856780.html |title=Naked March in Paris to Open New Office of Femen Feminist Group – SPIEGEL ONLINE |website=Der Spiegel |accessdate=2012-11-19}} (main headquarter) | key_people = [[Anna Hutsol]]
[[Oksana Shachko]]
[[Alexandra Shevchenko]]{{cite web|url=http://femen.org/en/news/id/216 |title=FEMEN |publisher=FEMEN |date=2013-01-24 |accessdate=2013-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509142453/http://femen.org/en/news/id/216 |archivedate= 9 May 2013 |df= }}
[[Inna Shevchenko]]
[[Yana Zhdanova]] | focus = [[Women's liberation]] | homepage = [http://femen.org/ femen.org] }} '''Femen''' ({{lang-uk|Фемен}}), stylized as '''FEMEN''', is a Ukrainian [[radical feminist]] activist group intended to protect [[women's rights]]. The organization became internationally known for organizing controversial{{cite web|url=http://www.movements.org/case-study/entry/ukraines-ladies-of-femen/ |title=Ukraine's Ladies Of Femen |publisher=Movements.org |date=2011-08-16 |accessdate=2013-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414005441/http://www.movements.org/case-study/entry/ukraines-ladies-of-femen |archivedate=14 April 2012 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|first=Jeffrey |last=Tayler |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/03/the-woman-behind-femens-topless-protest-movement/273970/ |title=The Woman Behind Femen's Topless Protest Movement|work=The Atlantic |date=13 March 2013|accessdate=2013-04-22}} [[topless protest]]s against [[sex tourism]],[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/65379/ Femen wants to move from public exposure to political power], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (28 April 2010) religious institutions, sexism, homophobia,{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/24/topless-femen-protest-andre-jozef-leonard_n_3146609.html|title=Topless FEMEN Protesters Drench Belgian Archbishop André-Jozef Léonard, Protest Homophobia In Catholic Church (PHOTOS)|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=23 March 2015|date=24 April 2013}} and other social, national, and international topics. Founded in Ukraine, the group is now based in Paris. The organization describes itself as "fighting [[patriarchy]] in its three [[:wiktionary:manifestations|manifestations]] – [[sexual exploitation]] of [[women]], [[dictatorship]] and [[religion]]" and has stated that its goal is "sextremism serving to protect women's rights".[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/20/femen-activists-uk-branch-feminism Fearless ... and topless: Femen activists to bring 'sextremism' to the UK], [[theguardian.com]] (19 October 2013) Femen activists have been regularly detained by police in response to their protests.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22881163 Femen activists jailed in Tunisia for topless protest], [[BBC News]] (12 June 2013){{cite news | url= http://rt.com/news/femen-protest-abortion-ukraine-705/| title= FEMEN rings the bell: Naked activists defend right to abortion | publisher= Russia Today | date= 10 April 2012}} ==History== [[File:FEMEN Swine Flu Panic Protest-13.jpg|thumb|left|Femen protest in [[Kiev]], 9 November 2009. Early protests were provocative but not topless.]] [[Anna Hutsol]] is credited as having founded the Femen movement on 10 April 2008, after she became aware of stories of [[Ukrainian woman|Ukrainian women]] duped into going abroad and then taken advantage of sexually.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/29898/ Feminine Femen targets 'sexpats'], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (22 May 2009)[http://observers.france24.com/en/content/20090828-how-they-protest-prostitution-ukraine-femen-sex-tourism How they protest prostitution in Ukraine], [[France 24]] (28 August 2009) However, according to the 2013 documentary by Kitty Green, ''[[Ukraine Is Not a Brothel]]'', Femen was founded by [[Viktor Sviatsky]]. In September 2013 [[Inna Shevchenko]] responded to the documentary stating that Sviatsky "did lead the movement some time ago. ...We accepted this because we did not know how to resist and fight it. ...This is when I decided to leave Ukraine for France to build a new Femen".[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/the-man-who-made-femen-new-film-outs-victor-svyatski-as-the-mastermind-behind-the-protest-group-and-its-breastbaring-stunts-8797042.html "The man who made Femen: New film outs Victor Svyatski as the mastermind behind the protest group and its breast-baring stunts"], ''[[The Independent]]''. 3 September 2013.[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/05/victory-svyatski-femen-man "Femen let Victor Svyatski take over because we didn't know how to fight it"], ''[[The Guardian]]''. 5 September 2013. Femen member Inna Shevchenko discussed Sviatsky with ''[[The Independent]]'' in January, 2014, and, while not using the word 'founder' said: "I will never deny that he is a smart person. He was the reason why we knew each other. He was one of those smart people around us at the beginning, who were more experienced".{{cite news | first = Geoffrey | last = McNabb | title = 'I don't want to be liked': Inna Shevchenko, leader of women's rights group Femen, talks dictators, documentaries and death threats | date = 17 January 2014 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/i-dont-want-to-be-liked-inna-shevchenko-leader-of-womens-rights-group-femen-talks-dictators-documentaries-and-death-threats-9062734.html | work = The Independent | accessdate = 2014-01-19 | location=London}} Since 2013 Femen has been led by [[Inna Shevchenko]]. Initially, Femen gained attention by demonstrating in skimpy or erotic clothing. For example, on 21 September 2008 in front of the Turkish embassy,{{where?|date=April 2014}} a dozen Femen members were dressed as nurses with smudged makeup and high pink heels; however, at the 24 August 2009 demonstration on Ukrainian independence day, [[Oksana Shachko]] went topless.{{fr icon}} [http://www.parismatch.com/Actu-Match/Monde/Actu/Femen-Les-feministes-venues-du-froid-377710/ Femen Les féministes venues du froid] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130110061537/http://www.parismatch.com/Actu-Match/Monde/Actu/Femen-Les-feministes-venues-du-froid-377710/# |date=10 January 2013 }}, ''[[Paris Match]]'' (18 February 2012) Since this approach obtained such great publicity, it rapidly became FEMEN's signature approach. While most of the protests have been confined to bare breasts, in October 2010 Shachko exposed her [[buttocks]] outside a locked toilet in a demonstration to protest the lack of [[public toilet]]s in [[Kiev]],[http://www.summitdaily.com/article/20101119/API/1011191413 Topless protesters gain fame in Ukraine], [[Associated Press]] (19 November 2010) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201180208/http://www.summitdaily.com/article/20101119/API/1011191413 |date=1 February 2012 }} and four of the group members staged a similar protest in Kiev in February 2011.[http://Kyivconnexions.blogspot.com/2011_02_01_archive.html ]{{dead link|date=November 2013}} [[File:Election Protest Crucified Ukraine.jpg|thumb|Femen protest in [[Kiev]] during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010#Second round ballot|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] against the election of [[Victor Yanukovych]]. The signs read "The War Begins Today" and "Stop Raping the Country."]] Since May 2011, a host of international news outlets have started to report about the organization's actions; this has sharply heightened FEMEN's international profile.{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2011/05/unorthodox_protest_ukraine|title=Unorthodox protest in Ukraine: Indecent exposure |publisher=The Economist |date=20 May 2011|accessdate=2013-04-22}}{{cite news|first=Benjamin|last=Bidder|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/Kyiv-s-topless-protestors-the-entire-ukraine-is-a-brothel-a-760697.html |title=Kyiv's Topless Protestors: 'The Entire Ukraine Is a Brothel'|work=Spiegel Online |date=5 May 2011|accessdate=2013-04-22}} From late 2011, the Ukrainian Femen activists started to hold more international protests.{{cite web |url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/societe/des-feministes-ukrainiennes-manifestent-contre-dsk_1046496.html |title=Des féministes ukrainiennes manifestent contre DSK |website=L'Express |date=2011-11-01 |accessdate=2013-04-22 }}
{{cite news |url=http://photos.independent.ie/gallery/Ukraine_Feminist_Protesters_/slideshow/Topless_Ukrainian_Activists/008J9Ob5j3chH |title=Ukrainian Femen Protesters - Irish Independent Galleries |publisher=Photos.independent.ie |date=2011-11-05 |accessdate=2013-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621133646/http://photos.independent.ie/gallery/Ukraine_Feminist_Protesters_/slideshow/Topless_Ukrainian_Activists/008J9Ob5j3chH |archivedate=21 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}
{{cite web |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine-abroad/bikyamasr-ukraine-woman-strips-at-vatican-for-righ-116435.html |title=Bikyamasr: Ukraine woman strips at Vatican for rights, anti-Berlusconi |publisher=Kyivpost.com |accessdate=2013-04-22 }}
{{cite web |url=http://www.mizozo.com/world/11/2011/10/femen-zurich-is-not-a-brothel-nsfw.html |title=FEMEN - Zurich is not a Brothel! (NSFW) |publisher=Mizozo.com |accessdate=2013-04-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416060342/http://www.mizozo.com/world/11/2011/10/femen-zurich-is-not-a-brothel-nsfw.html# |archive-date=16 April 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}
{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/264747/20111209/femen-stage-naked-protest-putin-moscow-photos.htm |title='Femen' Stage Naked Protest Against Putin in Moscow [PHOTOS] - IBTimes UK |publisher=Ibtimes.co.uk |date=2011-12-09 |accessdate=2013-04-22 }} In December 2011, three Femen activists stated that the [[State Security Committee of the Republic of Belarus]] had abducted and terrorized them after they staged topless protests in [[Minsk]].{{#tag:ref|On 19 December 2011 FEMEN performed a topless protest against Belarus President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] outside the KGB Headquarters in Minsk, mocking Lukashenko's recognizable haircut and moustache. Afterwards, according to FEMEN, the three protesters [[Inna Shevchenko]], [[Oksana Shachko]] and Aleksandra Nemchinova were abducted by the Belarus authorities and taken to a remote forest blindfolded, doused with oil, forced to strip and then threatened with being set on fire, before having their hair violently cut with knives and being abandoned in the snow half-naked.{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/femen_activists_detained_by_belarus_kgb/24428304.html |title=Ukrainian Activists Allegedly Kidnapped, Terrorized In Belarus Found |website=RFE/RL |accessdate=2013-04-22| date =20 December 2011}}{{cite news | title =Trio 'abducted and abused' for Belarus topless protest | publisher =BBC | date =20 December 2011 | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16275566 | accessdate = 13 January 2013}}|group=nb}} On 8 April 2013, five Femen members "topless ambushed" [[Russian President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] (accompanied by [[German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]]) at the [[Hanover trade fair]]. After [[Inna Shevchenko]] [[FEMEN#Protests against religious institutions|chopped down a wooden cross overlooking]] [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]] in Kiev on 17 August 2012, she stated that she had received several death threats and that her front door had been kicked in. Fearing arrest, she sought asylum in France and moved to [[Paris]]. There, in September 2012, she established a training facility for activists for [[FEMEN France|Femen in France]]. {{cite news|first=Kira |last=Cochrane |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/20/naked-female-warrior-femen-topless-protesters |title=Rise of the naked female warriors |work=The Guardian |accessdate=2013-04-22 |location=London |date=20 March 2013}} In late July 2013, one of the ideologists of the Femen, [[Viktor Sviatsky]],{{#tag:ref|Early September 2013 [[Inna Shevchenko]] stated that FEMEN had "broke free" of Sviatsky.|group=nb}} and Hutsol were assaulted on the eve of a visit by Putin to Kiev to celebrate the 1,025th anniversary of the [[Christianization of Kievan Rus']]. According to Hutsol, those who attacked them "resemble those cooperating with secret services [[Security Service of Ukraine|SBU]] and [[Federal Security Service|FSB]]".[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/femen-leader-points-to-russian-fingerprints-in-recent-attacks-on-groups-activists-in-kyiv/ Femen leader points to ‘Russian fingerprints’ in recent attacks on group’s activists in Kiev], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (29 July 2013)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/161896.html FEMEN says their male activist brutally beaten up by security services], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 July 2013)
[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/fined_femen_activists_planned_protest_against_putin_307085 Fined Femen activists planned protest against Putin], [[Ukrinform]] (29 July 2013)
[http://www.rferl.org/content/ukraine-russia-belarus-moldova-serbia-kievan-rus/25058270.html State Leaders, Orthodox Clergy Mark Kievan Rus Anniversary], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (27 July 2013)
[http://www.dw.de/attacks-were-meant-to-intimidate-us-femen/a-16985670 'Attacks were meant to intimidate us': Femen], [[Deutsche Welle]] (29 July 2013) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915104917/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/femen-leader-points-to-russian-fingerprints-in-recent-attacks-on-groups-activists-in-kyiv/ |date=15 September 2013 }} One of the founding members, Oksana Shachko, was found dead in Paris on 24 July, 2018; her death is believed to be a suicide. She was living as an independent artist separated from the group after disputes with other members.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/24/femen-co-founder-oksana-shachko-found-dead-paris-flat|title=Femen co-founder Oksana Shachko found dead in Paris flat|work=The Guardian|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=27 July 2018}} ==Organization== [[File:Fuck EURO2012.jpg|thumb|Femen protest against [[UEFA Euro 2012|EURO 2012]] on 8 June 2012]] Femen has [[FEMEN#International branches|several international branches]]. The Femen office in their native [[Kiev]] was closed and the organization's leadership left Ukraine ("Fearing for their lives and freedom") in August 2013. In October 2012, the organization stated it had about 40 activists in Ukraine, and another 100 who had joined their protests abroad, as well as twelve thousand followers via the [[social network]] [[Vkontakte]].{{cite web|url=http://vk.com/femen_femen|title=FEMEN|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} In October 2013, Femen had its largest membership in France. In January 2013, [[FEMEN France|Femen France]] counted 30 local activists. In 2010, the group comprised some 320 activists,[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6AE1FB20101115?pageNumber=2 Ukraine's topless group widens political role], [[Reuters]] (15 November 2010) with about 300 of the active participants being in Kiev. In a 2010 interview, [[Anna Hutsol]] said that in addition to 20 core organizers there are 300 activists in Kiev, as well as a [[social network]] based on [[vkontakte]] of about 20,000 persons.[http://focus.ua/society/132643/ "Девушки хотят. Интервью с Анной Гуцол, лидером FEMEN"], 15 July 2010, Анастасия Рингис, [[Focus (Ukrainian magazine)|''Focus'' (Ukrainian magazine)]] website (retrieved 6 February 2013) {{ru icon}} Female university students between 18 and 20 years old formed the backbone of the movement when it was formed in 2008, with few male members. In 2011, various sources stated that in an interview [[Anna Hutsol]] said that the movement has 150 thousand supporters.{{ru icon}} Maria Dmitrieva, [http://www.gender.univer.kharkov.ua/gurnal/20-21/26.pdf Радикальный эксгибиционизм] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907002631/http://www.gender.univer.kharkov.ua/gurnal/20-21/26.pdf |date= 7 September 2012 }} ("Radical Exhibitionism"); [http://www.chaskor.ru/article/radikalnyj_eksgibitsionizm_18186 first published] on the website ''Private Correspondent'' In October 2012, the organization said that it had about 40 activists in Ukraine, and another 100 who had joined their protests abroad. Hutsol stated in July 2010: "We are working better than any [[news agency]]. We have a photographer, [[cinematographer]], designer and [[content manager]]." In Ukraine, most of FEMEN's demonstrations are staged in Kiev, but the organization has also held actions in cities like [[Odessa]], [[Dnipropetrovsk]], and [[Zaporizhia]]. In April 2010 the organization contemplated becoming a [[political party]] to run for seats in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|October 2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]].{{ru icon}} [http://lenta.ru/articles/2012/02/15/femen/ Мужественный протест (The courageous protest)], [[Lenta.Ru]] (15 February 2012) However, it did not take part in these elections.{{uk icon}} [http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/wp400?PT001F01=900 Information on the registration of electoral lists of candidates], [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]
{{uk icon}} [http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/wp039?PT001F01=900 Results of voting in single constituencies in 2012] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127194105/http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/wp039?PT001F01=900 |date=27 November 2012 }} & [http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/wp400?PT001F01=900 Nation-wide list], [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826151733/http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/wp400?PT001F01=900 |date=26 August 2012 }} [[File:FEMEN "Blue Bucket" topless protest.jpg|thumb|Demonstration in front of the [[List of diplomatic missions of Russia|Russian embassy]] in Kiev in May 2010]] Femen explained its methodology of topless protesting by saying: "This is the only way to be heard in this country. If we staged simple protests with banners, then our claims would not have been noticed".[http://rt.com/news/ukraine-femen-sex-tourism "Ukraine is not a bordello"], [[Russia Today]] (14 December 2009) The organization plans to become the biggest and the most influential movement in [[Europe]].[http://www.myspace.com/femenukraine FEMEN], Organisations [[MySpace]] page [[Facebook]] initially blocked the Femen page because it suspected it was [[pornographic]]. In addition, Femen has displayed several provocative images on its Facebook page, including images of Femen activists taking a [[chainsaw]] to the heads of [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[Kirill I of Moscow]], who were depicted covered in blood.{{cite news | url = http://www.lesnouvellesnews.fr/index.php/contre-courant-articles-section/contre-courant/2083-apres-les-guitares-de-pussy-riot-la-tronconneuse-de-femen | title = Après les guitares de Pussy Riot, la tronçonneuse de Femen | publisher = Les Nouvelles Calédoniennes | page = | date = 20 August 2012 }} In 2010 and 2011, Ukrainian members had stated that their involvement in Femen had caused their families to become alienated from them. Some Femen members, including Inna Shevchenko, have also been subject to threats, kidnapping, beating and other intimidation.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/topless-protester-was-abducted-and-beaten-in-belarus-6280702.html|title=Topless protester was 'abducted and beaten' in Belarus|work=[[The Independent]]|date=2011-12-23|location=London|first=Jerome|last=Taylor}} ===Criminal cases against the organization=== Several criminal cases have been opened against the organization in Ukraine on charges of "[[hooliganism]]" and "[[Flag desecration|desecration of state symbols]]", among others, and the group has been [[Fine (penalty)|fined]].{{ru icon}} [http://news.liga.net/news/politics/609761-na_femenistok_zaveli_dva_ugolovnykh_dela_za_obnazhenku.htm&usg На FEMENисток завели два уголовных дела за "обнаженку"], Информационно-аналитический центр "ЛІГА" (17 February 2012) In addition, most Femen activists are detained by the police after protesting; in one case, the [[State Security Committee of the Republic of Belarus]] arrested Femen activists, "threatening them with knives and cutting their hair". According to Femen, after [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|the early 2010 election]] of [[Ukrainian President|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]], the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] attempted to intimidate the Femen activists. The [[Ukrainian police]] opened a criminal case against Femen when during its 27 August 2013 raid in the movement's Kiev office it purportedly found a [[TT pistol]] and a grenade. Femen stated that these items were planted there by the Ukrainian police as part of a conspiracy by the [[Federal Security Service|Russian]] and [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian secret service]]s to prosecute the movement, which the police denied.[https://archive.is/20130828153947/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/police-seize-tt-pistol-and-grenade-in-kyiv-office-of-femen-womens-rights-group/ Police seize TT pistol and grenade in Kyiv office of Femen women’s rights group], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 August 2013)[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/27/femen-ukraine-police-planting-guns Femen accuses Kiev police of planting guns during raid], [[The Guardian]] (27 August 2013)[https://archive.is/20130906191109/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/femen-womens-rights-group-protests-outside-ukrainian-embassies-in-europe-following-search-of-kyiv-office/ FEMEN women’s rights group protests outside Ukrainian embassies in Europe following search of Kyiv office], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (29 August 2013){{#tag:ref|On 28 August 2013 a Kiev police spokesperson stated no one in the group had been charged but the criminal probe into illegal possession of weapons by the group continued and the women could be called in for further questioning.[http://www.news24.com/World/News/Femen-moves-out-of-bugged-Kiev-office-20130828 Femen moves out of 'bugged' Kiev office], [[News24]] (28 August 2013)|group=nb}} On 30 August 2013, Femen activist [[Yana Zhdanova]], [[Anna Hutsol]] and [[Alexandra Shevchenko]] were called in for questioning; instead (according to a Femen statement), "fearing for their lives and freedom the activists escaped from Ukraine to [[Europe]] to continue Femen activities" (also in Ukraine [as Hutsol had stated three days before she left Ukraine]).{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/08/31/6997008/ Активістки Femen втекли з України ''Femen activists fled from Ukraine''], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (31 August 2013){{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/08/27/6996762/ Femen закриє офіс в Україні, але діяльність не припинить ''Femen closes office in Ukraine, however, the activities do not stop''], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (27 August 2013) The Kiev office became a (not Femen-affiliated) bookstore on 23 October 2013.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/10/23/7000584/ У колишньому офісі Femen відкрили книжкову крамницю ''In the former office Femen opened a bookstore''], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (23 October 2013) By early March, Hutsol said that although [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|the regime that had criminally probed them had fallen]], it was "too risky to return to Ukraine"; in a February 2014 interview, Hutsol also stated that Femen activists who had stayed in Ukraine had helped during the [[Euromaidan]] protests that ultimately toppled this regime.{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Ellen|title=Ukraine Femen leader asks for Swiss asylum (update)|url=http://genevalunch.com/2014/03/01/ukraine-femen-leader-asks-for-swiss-asylum-update/|work=GenevaLunch News|date=1 March 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Clot|first1=Lioudmila|translator-first=Julia |translator-last=Bassam|title=‘Breasts are easy to get through metal detectors’|url=http://origin.swissinfo.ch/eng/-breasts-are-easy-to-get-through-metal-detectors-/38212264|work=SWI|date=27 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://euroradio.fm/en/croissant|title=Femen: Our war is somewhat different from Maidan|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2015}} Femen actions did recur in Kiev in the summer of 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/watch/nbcnews-com/topless-trio-arrested-during-ukraine-protest-33976387817|title=Topless trio arrested during Ukraine protest|website=NBC News|accessdate=23 March 2015}} Femen protests have also been said to result in destruction of public property.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/17/pussy-riot-trial-femen_n_1798009.html|title=LOOK: Topless Activist Chainsaws Crucifix In Support Of Pussy Riot|first=Dominique |last=Mosbergen|website=The Huffington Post|date=17 August 2012|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} ===International branches=== ====Femen France==== {{Main article|FEMEN France}} [[File:Bare breasts are our weapons crop.jpg|thumb|A [[Femen France]] protester, 2012]] Femen France is the [[France|French]] branch of Femen. After cutting down a [[crucifix]] near [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]] in Kiev in August 2012,{{cite news | url = http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=9749 | title = Cross sawn down by FEMEN activists in Kiev turned out to be Catholic, not Orthodox | publisher = Interfax | page = | date = 20 August 2012 }} [[Inna Shevchenko]] left the country and went to Paris to set up [[FEMEN France|Femen France]], a training center for activists.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/cross-chopping-topless-activist-flees-ukraine-8798.html |title=Cross-chopping topless activist flees Ukraine |publisher=Indiatvnews.com |date=6 September 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-10}} The international training center opened on 18 September 2012. As of early January 2013, the organization consisted of 30 local activists. The only [[Ukrainians]] regularly present were [[Oksana Shachko]] and [[Inna Shevchenko]].[https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/01/femen-in-paris-ukraines-topless-warriors-move-west/266755/ Femen in Paris: Ukraine's Topless Warriors Move West], [[The Atlantic]] (2 January 2013) On 6 March 2013, Femen activists, together with French writer Galia Ackerman, released their first book, ''Femen''. The book was published by Calmann-Lévy.{{cite web | title = FEMEN Book (2013) | publisher = FEMEN.info | date = 6 March 2013 | url = http://femen.info/books/femen-book-2013/ | accessdate = 23 March 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6FeNZMha1?url=http://femen.info/books/femen-book-2013/ | archivedate = 5 April 2013 | df = dmy-all }} The international training center opened on 18 September 2012. 15 activists marched topless from the metro station [[Château Rouge]] to the Lavoir Moderne Parisien, where their new headquarters are located, and organized a press conference there.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/naked-march-in-paris-to-open-new-office-of-femen-feminist-group-a-856780.html |title=Naked March in Paris to Open New Office of Femen Feminist Group - SPIEGEL ONLINE |publisher=Spiegel.de |accessdate=2012-11-19}} On 3 October 2012, French activists Éloïse Bouton, Elvire Duvelle-Charles, Miyabi K., Julia Javel, Jenny Bah, Nathalie Vignes and Inna Shevchenko protested against [[rape]] by standing topless in front of the [[Venus de Milo]] statue in the [[Louvre Museum]]. The Femen activists shouted, "We have hands to stop rape". They stated they chose the Venus de Milo because it has no arms, arguing this best symbolizes a woman’s helplessness and vulnerability. This protest followed an incident in [[Tunisia]] where a woman faced charges of indecency after she said she was raped by police officers.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/art-and-culture/news/topless-louvre-rape-protest-575/ |title=Topless at the Louvre: FEMEN activists stage anti-rape protest — RT |publisher=Rt.com |accessdate=2012-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013005315/http://rt.com/art-and-culture/news/topless-louvre-rape-protest-575/ |archivedate=13 October 2012 |df= }} [[File:FEMEN 15 oct 2012-e.jpg|thumb|180px|Demonstration by Femen in Paris, 15 October 2012]] On 15 October 2012, eight topless activists protested in front of the French [[Ministry of Justice]] at the [[Place Vendôme]] in [[Paris]] in response to the verdict in the trial of fourteen men for the [[gang rape]] of teenage girls.{{cite web |url=http://avaxnews.com/fact/Topless_FEMEN_Activists_Attempt_French_Justice_Ministry_Break-In.html |title=Topless FEMEN Activists Attempt French Justice Ministry Break-In |publisher=Avaxnews.com |date=2012-10-16 |accessdate=2012-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018195450/http://avaxnews.com/fact/Topless_FEMEN_Activists_Attempt_French_Justice_Ministry_Break-In.html# |archive-date=18 October 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} After a four-week trial in [[Fontenay-sous-Bois]] near Paris, four of the accused were found guilty of taking part in gang rapes, ten were acquitted.{{cite news|first=Angelique |last=Chrisafis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/11/gang-rape-trial-france |title=Four guilty in gang-rape trial that shocked France |work=The Guardian |accessdate=2012-11-19 |location=London |date=11 October 2012}} The sentences were far lighter than those recommended by the state prosecutor, who had called for prison sentences of five to seven years for eight of the men. The protesters accused the French authorities of tolerating the rape of minors. Femen activists held protests in front of [[Great Mosque of Paris]] on 3 April 2013, to demand the release of [[Amina Tyler]], a Femen activist in Tunisia. They also burned the [[Salafist]] flag.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} In September 2015 two topless Femen activists jumped onto the stage of a conservative Muslim conference in Paris.{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20150914-femen-topless-protest-french-islam-conference |title=Femen activists in topless protest at French Islam conference on women |publisher=France 24 |date=15 September 2015 |accessdate=13 October 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.rt.com/news/315221-femen-france-muslim-disrupt/ |title=Topless FEMEN activists disrupt Muslim conference in France (VIDEO) |newspaper=RT |date=13 September 2015 |accessdate=13 October 2015}} ====Other branches==== Since late 2011, Femen has held rallies outside Ukraine.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/ukraine/detail/116367/ FEMEN participate in Berlusconi protests], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (2 November 2011)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/ukraine/detail/118567/ Huffington Post: FEMEN, Ukrainian women's rights group, protests Russian election], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (9 December 2011)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/119327/ Ukraine topless activists raise SOS from Belarus], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (20 December 2011)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/123974/ Turkey acts to better protect women from abuse], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (9 March 2012)[https://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2012/03/04/naked-protesters-draw-attention-at-moscow-polling-station/ Naked Protesters Draw Attention at Moscow Polling Station], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' (4 March 2012) In late April 2011, the organization said it was setting up international branches in [[Warsaw]], [[Zürich]], [[Rome]], [[Tel Aviv]], and [[Rio de Janeiro]]. A demonstration by a group called RU Femen in the Russian capital, [[Moscow]], in late April 2011{{ru icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110429231010/http://www.lifenews.ru/video/2671 Полуголые активистки прошлись по Москве], [[LifeNews|L!FE NEWS]] (27 April 2011) was immediately denounced as a fake offspring of Femen. Femen accused the Russian political party [[United Russia]] of having set up RU Femen.{{uk icon}} [http://blogs.pravda.com.ua/authors/femen/4db9723c85278/ На FEMEN здiйснена рейдерська атака! Клятi москалi! Перший пост без цицьок], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (28 April 2011){{ru icon}} [https://archive.is/20121129131713/http://femen.livejournal.com/149357.html Зассанные кремлевские матрасы!], [[LiveJournal]] blog of FEMEN (28 April 2011) Early in 2013, Femen said that it had members in [[Brazil]], Germany, the [[United States|U.S.]], Canada, Switzerland, Italy, [[Bulgaria]], and [[Tunisia]]. On 23 January 2013, a third national Femen-group was opened officially when [[Alexandra Shevchenko]] launched Femen in Germany proposing to train and lead the group from [[Berlin]] and [[Hamburg]] bases.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/bare-chested-protesters-take-on-berlin/a-16627222 |title=Bare-chested protesters take on Berlin |publisher=DW.DE |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-12}} The German branch of Femen was founded by [[Zana Ramadani]]. An action the group took was amid the opening of the [[Barbie]] Dream House in Berlin's [[Alexanderplatz]]. Right before the pink plastic building opened, a Femen member emerged topless from a model high-heel shoe burning a Barbie doll, in protest of what was widely seen as giving girls an unrealistic view of life. The Femen member had written on her chest LIFE IN PLASTIC IS NOT FANTASTIC.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/femen-berlin-barbie-dream-house-topless-468268|title=Femen Topless Protester Burns Barbie on Cross in Dream House Protest [PHOTOS]|first=Umberto|last=Bacchi|date=16 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} A [[Quebec]]-based Femen is also active, founded by Ukraine-born, [[Sept-Îles, Quebec|Sept-Îles]] raised Xenia Chernyshova.{{cite web |language=French |last= Allard |first=Sophie |title=Notre arme est le sein nu |publisher=Plus.lapresse.ca | date=27 April 2013 |url=http://plus.lapresse.ca/screens/4671-d5c0-51795a58-90a7-35a6ac1c6068%7C.WHa1rfVIT.S}}{{cite news|last=Edmiston|first=Jake|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/06/03/femen/ |title='My breasts become political': How a topless Montreal protestor invaded the speech of a former Tunisian PM |work=National Post |date=3 June 2003}} On 10 September 2013, the Belgium branch of Femen voluntary disbanded itself.{{#tag:ref|The reason given on its [[Facebook page]] was: "disagreement about the internal organization within the international movement Femen".|group=nb}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/binnenland/aid1451273/belgische-femen-tak-stopt.aspx |title=Belgische Femen-afdeling stopt ''Belgian Femen-branch stops'' |publisher= [[Gazet van Antwerpen]] |date=11 September 2013 |language=Dutch}} A branch of Femen in [[Turkey]], founded in late-2013 is also active.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/FEMEN_Turkey|title=FEMEN Turkey|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/1.582850|title=Femen activists stage anti-Erdogan protest at Istanbul polling station|date=30 March 2014|website=Haaretz.com|accessdate=23 March 2015}} In June 2014, Femen opened a branch in Israel with 15 women. Femen notes, "our numbers are growing from week to week." The members, who range in age from 17 to 30, come from all over the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/.premium-1.599472|title=Exposing Israelis to radical feminism|date=17 June 2014|website=Haaretz.com|accessdate=23 March 2015}} In August 2016, a branch of Femen launched in the United States of America, based in Seattle, Washington and led by Jordan Robson. To date, their most publicized action has been a protest held at the polling station used by [[Donald Trump]] in New York City on November 8, 2016. http://q13fox.com/2016/11/08/topless-protesters-crash-donald-trumps-manhattan-polling-place/ ==Goals and stances== {{Primary sources|section|date=May 2013}} [[File:Manifestation pour le mariage pour tous Paris Femen 16 12 2012 15.jpg|thumb|190px|Demonstration in support of same-sex marriage in Paris, 16 December 2012]] Femen describes its stance as "radical [[feminism]]", and says that it is "fighting [[patriarchy]] in its three [[:wiktionary:manifestations|manifestations]] - [[sexual exploitation]] of [[women]], [[dictatorship]] and [[religion]]". Femen has pledged to fight the sex industry and [[International marriage agencies|marriage agencies]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/femen-opens-turkey-office.aspx?pageID=238&nID=56835&NewsCatID=341|title=FEMEN opens Turkey office - LOCAL|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2015}} the Church and its [[Christianity and abortion#Eastern Orthodox Church|pro-life beliefs]]{{cite web |title=Alarm Bell |url=http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/51#post-content |publisher=Femen.org |date=4 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221125604/http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/51#post-content |archivedate=21 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/news/femen-protest-abortion-ukraine-705/ |title=FEMEN rings the bell: Naked activists defend right to abortion |publisher=Rt.com |date=10 April 2012}} and [[patriarchal society]], as well as those who oppose gay marriage. Femen has expressed opposition against [[Islamism]],{{cite web |url=http://femen.org/en/news/id/126#post-content |title=Freedom for Women in the East |publisher=Femen.org |date=10 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120104135/http://femen.org/en/news/id/126#post-content |archivedate=20 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }} "[[Sharia law]]"{{cite web |url=http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/54#post-content |title=Allah Created Me Naked! |publisher=Femen.org |date=31 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215211742/http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/54#post-content |archivedate=15 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} and spoken against the practice of [[female genital mutilation]] (FGM).{{cite web |url=http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/132#post-content |title=Berlinale, There Is Not Only Film That Can Be Cut! Stop FGM! |publisher=Femen.org |date=7 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211020759/http://femen.org/en/gallery/id/132#post-content |archivedate=11 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} On its official website Femen states: "Femen – is sextremism serving to protect women's rights, democracy watchdogs attacking patriarchy, in all its forms: the dictatorship, the church, the sex industry".[http://femen.org/en/about FEMEN: FEMEN - is a global women's movement], Official FEMEN website Femen has expressed both support for and opposition against various public figures and organizations; for example, the group lauded [[Pussy Riot]]"[http://femen.org/gallery/id/21 Free Riot] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312000907/http://femen.org/gallery/id/21 |date=12 March 2013 }}". ''Femen.org'' (25 January 2013) In late May 2009, Femen proposed the introduction of criminal responsibility for the use of sex industry services.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/41956/ FEMEN initiates criminal responsibility for using sex industry services], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (22 May 2009) Femen protested against what they argued were moves being made by the Ukrainian government to legalize [[prostitution]] during the [[UEFA Euro 2012|EURO 2012]] championships.{{cite news|title=Ukraine women go topless against UEFA, prostitution |url=http://bikyamasr.com/50158/ukraine-women-go-topless-against-uefa-prostitution/ |date=3 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402050509/http://bikyamasr.com/50158/ukraine-women-go-topless-against-uefa-prostitution/ |archivedate=2 April 2012 }} The group asked [[UEFA]] and the Ukrainian government to create a social program devoted to the problem of [[sex tourism]] and [[prostitution in Ukraine]]; to inform football fans that prostitution is illegal in Ukraine; and to take additional steps to fight against prostitution and sex tourism.{{cite news|title=Euro 2012 Without Prostitution: Femen Activists Go Topless Against UEFA |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/11012768/content/88682764-ukrainian-police-arrest-protesters-of-women-activist-group-femen-during-a-demonstration |date=2 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108045934/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/11012768/content/88682764-ukrainian-police-arrest-protesters-of-women-activist-group-femen-during-a-demonstration |archivedate=8 January 2012 }}{{#tag:ref|As a counter-act [[Prostitution in Poland|Polish prostitutes]] held their own nude demonstration (in masks) with the catchphrase "Femen! Get the fuck out of our business".{{uk icon}} [http://fakty.ictv.ua/ru/index/read-news/id/1450841 Польские проститутки ответили Femen ''Polish prostitutes replied Femen''], [[ICTV (Ukraine)|ICTV]] (12 June 2012)|group=nb}} Despite Femen's objection to the sex industry, the group has fought against the prosecution of [[Anastasia Grishay]] by Ukrainian authorities (initiated by a prominent [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist]] [[Verkhovna Rada|member of parliament]]){{cite web|url=http://femen.org/en/news/id/169#post-content|title=Save my children!|date=12 June 2012|publisher=FEMEN|accessdate=2013-08-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112101118/http://femen.org/en/news/id/169#post-content|archivedate=12 November 2013|df=dmy-all}} on grounds of her [[Pornography by region#Ukraine|involvement in pornography]].{{cite news |url= http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayinski-pravoohoronci-znovu-vzyalisya-za-spravu-v-yakiy-figuruye-pornozirka-wiska.html |title= Українські правоохоронці знову взялися за справу, в якій фігурує порнозірка Wiska |date= 2012-12-10 |accessdate= 2013-08-13 |agency= [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] |language= Ukrainian}}"[http://femen.org/en/news/id/169#post-content Save My Children!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112101118/http://femen.org/en/news/id/169 |date=12 November 2013 }}". Before she was able to steal the statue, however, she was tackled to the ground by guards.{{cite news |title=Topless Femen activist arrested trying to snatch Jesus statue from Vatican nativity scene |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/topless-feminist-femen-ukraine-god-is-woman-steal-jesus-statue-vatican-st-peter-s-square-pope-a8128431.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=27 December 2017}} ==Amina Tyler case== [[File:Amina Tyler.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|[[Amina Tyler|Amina "Tyler" Sboui]]]] {{Main article|Amina Tyler}} '''Amina Tyler''' (real name Amina Sboui), a [[Tunisia]]n Femen activist, was arrested on 19 May 2013 in [[Tunis]]. International protests followed for her release from detention. On 12 June 2013 a Tunisian judge convicted two French Femen members and one German Femen member after they were charged with public indecency while protesting for the release of Tyler. Pauline Hillier, Marguerite Stern and [[Josephine Markmann]] were released on 26 June 2013 after a Tunisian court lifted their prison sentence.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/27/femen-activists-tunisia-retract-apology Femen activists jailed in Tunisia retract apology], [[The Guardian]] (27 June 2013) Amina Tyler was acquitted for contempt and defamation on 29 July 2013; but she remained jailed pending trial on a separate charge of desecrating a cemetery.[http://www.france24.com/en/20130729-tunisia-femen-activist-amina-acquitted-contempt-defamation-charges Tunisian Femen activist ‘acquitted’ of defamation], [[France 24]] (29 July 2013)
[https://archive.is/20130730154531/http://m.timesdaily.com/news/world/article_33b2ca10-7b84-5cf8-8a4b-120a82f47f4d.html?mode=jqm Court dismisses 1 charge against Tunisian feminist], [[TimesDaily]] (29 July 2013)
[http://www.voanews.com/content/tunisian-femen-activist-acquitted-of-defamation-unrest-grows/1712301.html Tunisian Activist Acquitted Amid Growing Unrest], [[Voice of America]] (29 July 2013) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105050512/http://www.france24.com/en/20130729-tunisia-femen-activist-amina-acquitted-contempt-defamation-charges |date=5 November 2015 }} Femen had staged protests in front of the [[Grand Mosque of Paris]] burning a [[Tawhid]] flag. Amina upon release in August 2013 from detention in a Tunisian jail declared she was leaving the group in protest adding that she thought FEMEN's actions in Paris were disrespectful to the [[Muslim world]] and because she saw a lack of financial transparency in the organization.https://www.vocativ.com/08-2013/topless-tunisian-teen-activist-dumps-femen-but-still-takes-naked-selfies/

Positive remarks in Ukraine about Femen came from Maria Mayerchyk (of [[Lviv University]]), who has spoken about Femen, saying that they are a "positive, radical and important phenomenon that is able to raise social issues", and Larysa Kobelianska (UN-led women's rights program) said the group has succeeded in attracting public attention to women's problems, even if by questionable means.Hankivsky, Olena; Salnykova, Anastasiya. A Ukrainian [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] journalist, who claimed (in September 2012) to have infiltrated the organisation, says that its office in the Ukrainian capital, [[Kiev]], costs the movement over [[US Dollar|$]]2,500 per month, on top of which each member’s salary was roughly $1,000 per month.[http://rt.com/art-and-culture/femen-topless-activist-feminist-665/ Boob job: FEMEN activist reveals topless protesters’ $1,000 salaries] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019020542/http://rt.com/art-and-culture/femen-topless-activist-feminist-665/ |date=19 October 2013 }}, [[RT (TV network)|RT]] (21 September 2012) ==See also== {{Portal|Politics|Ukraine|2010s}} * [[Feminism]] * [[Gender equality]] * [[History of feminism]] * [[Nudity and protest]] * [[Postfeminism]] * [[Sex-positive feminism]] * [[Women's Equality Day]] * [[Women's rights in Ukraine]] ==Bibliography== * Ackerman, Galia; et al., ''Femen'', Published by Calmann-Lévy (Paris 2013), 280 pages. {{ISBN|978-2702144589}}. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[image:Council of Europe Film Award (FACE).jpg|thumb|Council of Europe - Council of Europe Film Award (FACE) ]] --> The '''Council of Europe Film Award (FACE)''' is presented at the [[Istanbul International Film Festival]] by the [[Council of Europe]] to the director whose entry to the festival raises public awareness and interest in [[human rights]] issues and promotes a better understanding of their significance.
==Philosophy==
The presentation of the FACE award is destined to honour an artistic or documentary film that raises the profile of human rights in accordance with the values of the Council of Europe and the principles it stands for: individual freedom, political liberty and the [[rule of law]]. The philosophy underlying the award's creation is the belief in the ability of film to transport its own message of human rights, tolerance and social inclusion to a wide audience. Cinema is not only an important expression of European culture, it is also a compass that can help to map out a route towards the Europe of the future – one that celebrates diversity and difference, that promotes equal opportunities for all its citizens, and that challenges abuse and intolerance.
==Procedure and prize==
The contribution winning the FACE award is selected by a jury from the entries in the "Human Rights in Cinema" section of the festival. This includes both [[documentary film|documentaries]] and [[feature film]]s investigating social change and individual dramas.
The FACE award consists of a sculpture in bronze (created by Freddy Ruhlman, entitled "Spirale de l'élévation") and a cash prize of 10000 €, which is offered in association with [[Eurimages]], the Council of Europe fund for the co-production, distribution and exhibition of European cinematographic works.
On 17 April 2010, [[Maud de Boer-Buquicchio]], Deputy Secretary General of the Council of Europe, presented the fourth Film Award of the Council of Europe (FACE) to Scandar Copti and Yaron Shani, during the closing ceremony of the 29th international film festival in Istanbul. ''The reason why we decided to team up with the prestigious Istanbul Film Festival is simple: while we believe that films cannot change the world, they can make us reflect and challenge us to change the world ourselves. This is all the more true when human rights are at stake,'' she emphasised.
In 2009, [[Maud de Boer-Buquicchio]] presented the third Film Award of the Council of Europe (FACE) to Marco Bechis on 18 April.
The 2008 Council of Europe Film Award was presented on April 19, by [[Maud de Boer-Buquicchio]], Deputy Secretary General of the Council of Europe.<ref name="fest">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Human Rights in Cinema | work = | publisher = [[Istanbul International Film Festival]], Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts | date = | url = http://www.iksv.org/film/english/program.asp?Content=Program&SID=4 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-03}}</ref>
On 14 April 2007, the first Council of Europe Film Award was presented by [[Thomas Hammarberg]], the Council of Europe Human Rights Commissioner, in the name of the [[Secretary General of the Council of Europe]], [[Terry Davis (politician)|Terry Davis]].<ref name="coe2007">{{cite web | last = Council of Europe Press Division | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = "Bamako", winner of the first Council of Europe film award in Istanbul | work = | publisher = [[Council of Europe]] Directorate of Communication | date = | url = http://www.coe.int/t/dc/files/events/2007_prix_film_istanbul/face-films-synopses_2008_fr.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-04}}</ref> Since then, the FACE award has been established as an annual collaboration between the International Istanbul Film Festival and the Council of Europe.
==The Council of Europe and the Istanbul International Film Festival==
[[Turkey]], a long-standing member of the 47 nation Council of Europe, has a long and proud tradition of film making. Between 1950 and 1970 it topped the league of the world’s most prolific film industries. Many of the films have reflected the changes in Turkish society, holding up a mirror to topics as diverse as domestic violence and the role of women, the problems of migration from the countryside and poverty in the cities. These films have served to boost inclusiveness and respect for human rights.
At the same time, [[Cinema of Turkey|Turkish film makers]] have suffered the same problems in recent years as their colleagues elsewhere; the drying up of funding, increased competition from the big players and the challenges of new technology. The Council of Europe manages Eurimages, the body that funds the co-production and distribution of films and fosters co-operation between professionals. It is also home to the European Audiovisual Observatory, the only centre of its kind to gather and circulate information on the audiovisual industry in Europe, including cinema, television and radio.
==Award holders==
* 2010: ''[[Ajami (film)|Ajami]]'' by Scandar Copti and Yaron Shani. The decision of the Human Rights Jury was announced by its President [[Marco Bechis]], winner of FACE in 2009 for “Birdwatchers”, who described ''[[Ajami (film)|Ajami]]'' as an “original tale of a multilayered society where different religions, beliefs, traditions and interests have to co-exist”. “The two directors have skilfully found the right cinematographic language to tell this powerful story,” the jury said. ''[[Ajami (film)|Ajami]]'' takes its name from a multi-ethnic neighbourhood in Jaffa, Israel. The film starts with a revenge killing, a case of mistaken identity whose repercussions lead to tragic results. The Jury Special Mention went to Philippe Van Leeuw for “The Day God Walked Away”.<ref>[http://www.coe.int/t/dc/files/events/2007_prix_film_istanbul/default_en.asp Council of Europe Film Award (FACE)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709174616/http://www.coe.int/t/dc/files/events/2007_prix_film_istanbul/default_en.asp |date=2010-07-09 }}</ref> * 2009: ''[[BirdWatchers (film)|Birdwatchers]]'' by [[Marco Bechis]]: “In today’s expanding world, respect for native populations and minorities is essential. By conveying this important message in a very well constructed story, ''Birdwatchers'' describes the complexities of changing society”; Jury members also decided to reward [[Nandita Das]] with a Special Jury Prize, for her film ''[[Firaaq]]'' which “courageously deals with the highly sensitive theme of religious intolerance and sectarian strife: showing its terrible consequences, ''Firaaq'' also conveys a message of hope and demonstrates that people can make choices.” * 2008: ''[[Blind Mountain|Mang Shan / Blind Mountain]]'' by [[Li Yang (director)|Li Yang]] "for its powerful message against all violence, no matter its form to women all over the world, because this message is both universal and timeless." ''Blind Mountain'' tells the story of a young student travelling to the north of China in pursuit of employment. The girl is abducted and sold as bride in an isolated village located deep in the mountains. Through her story, the film highlights the torment caused by human trafficking and violence against women.<ref name="fest"/><ref name="fest08">{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Awards of the 27th International İstanbul Film Festival |work= |publisher=[[Istanbul International Film Festival]], Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts |date= |url=http://www.iksv.org/film/english/film.asp?cid=386 |format= |doi= |accessdate=2008-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707153635/http://www.iksv.org/film/english/film.asp?Cid=386 |archivedate=2009-07-07 |df= }}</ref><ref name="coe2008">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Council of Europe Film Award (FACE) | work = | publisher = [[Council of Europe]] | date = | url = http://www.coe.int/t/dc/files/events/2007_prix_film_istanbul/face-films-synopses_2008_fr.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-04-04}}</ref>
* 2007: ''[[Bamako (film)|Bamako / ''The Court'']]'', directed by [[Abderrahmane Sissako]], a [[Mali]]an director, whose film explored the exploitation of Africa by other world powers. ''Bamako'' shows a community “court” where the people of Mali can find justice. “''Equality, full respect for human rights and the active involvement of ordinary citizens are needed to ensure social justice, and are necessary for any social and economic development. For this reason the jury has decided to award the FACE award to Bamako / The Court''”<ref name="coe2007"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{nofootnotes|date=October 2008}} '''Food testing strips''' are products that help determine whether or not food contains bacteria that can cause [[foodborne illness]]. These products can typically be used on food, water, and hard surfaces, and are often designed for quick and easy home and commercial use.
==Categories== Currently, there are two categories of food testing strips on the market.
One type of food testing strip is an assay enzyme reactant test. This test requires the food testing strip to be dipped into a blended mixture of food or test samples, distilled water and a reagent. These strips are designed specifically to detect those strains of ''[[Escherichia coli|E.coli]]'' and ''[[Salmonella]]'' that are harmful to humans.
A second type of food testing strip is a gram-negative swab, which is usually administered directly to the food itself. Gram-negative swabs generally work faster than enzyme reactant strips, but they differ in that the gram-negative swabs are designed to detect a broad group of organisms, not just those that can cause foodborne illness in humans.
<!-- images currently missing: [[Image:Salmonella strip wiki.JPG|thumb|220px|left|Sample Salmonella Test Strip]][[Image: E-Coli_strip_wiki.JPG|thumb|220px|Sample E.coli Test Strip]] -->
== Usage == The enzyme reactant test strips react when the buffer solution breaks the bacterial wall. This breach releases enzymes, which react upon contact to the enzyme test strips.
The gram-negative reactant activates when components of the gram-negative cell wall or specific enzymes are present, causing the swab itself to change color. This is not directly indicative of the presence or absence of human pathogen in the test sample.
People are now working on new ways to enhance these pathogen strips with silk pills and new nano-fiber technology.
==References== {{ref begin}} *Olafsdotti, Sigridur and Olaffson, D.R. "02/15/05" United States Patent {{US patent|6855332|#6855332}} Washington D.C. United States Patent and Trademark Office *Zakrzewski, Z., et al., "The Effects of Adjuvants on the Physical Properties and Active-Substance Release from Oral Suspensions," Goldschmidt Informiert, 57:14-17 (1982). *Lowenkamp, Bill “Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for ''Salmonella/E.Coli'' Testing strips“ Hazleshurst, MS Lowenkamp Labs (2007) {{ref end}}
==External links== *[http://www.accessexcellence.org/WN/SUA08/ecoli12.html Article on Instant Test Strips by Sean Henahan, Access Excellence]

{{Infobox organization |image = [[File:FFP Logo 2011.png|220px|FFP's logo adopted in 2011]] |caption = |motto = Promoting Sustainable Security |formation = 1957 |type = [[Research center]], [[think tank]] |headquarters = 1101 14th Street NW |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = J.J. Messner |name = The Fund for Peace |abbreviation = FFP |location = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] |website = [http://global.fundforpeace.org/ fundforpeace.org]
[http://fragilestatesindex.org/ fragilestatesindex.org] }} The '''Fund for Peace''' is a [[US]] [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]], [[non-governmental organization|non-governmental]] research and educational institution. Founded in 1957, FFP "works to prevent violent conflict and promote sustainable [[International security|security]]." The Fund for Peace works towards sustainable security and development in [[failed state]]s by focusing on conflict assessment and early warning, transnational threats, [[peacekeeping]], and security and [[human rights]].Fund for Peace [http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=435&Itemid=598 "Mission"]. The Fund for Peace maintains programs in [[Nigeria]], [[Uganda]], [[Liberia]], and works with private business in conflict zones to better secure the interests of businesses, local populations, and their governments. FFP publishes the annual [[Failed States Index|Fragile States Index]], used by researchers, educators, and governments across the world. ==History== The Fund for Peace was founded in 1957 by Randolph Compton. The organization was created in the memory of Randolph Compton's youngest son, John Parker Compton, who was killed in [[World War II]]. At a young age, John Parker wrote an essay, discussing the effects of war and the need for human civilization to embrace other methods of conflict resolution. After John Parker's death, Compton created the Fund for Peace, an organization based on the ideals of justice, environment, peace, and population.Fund for Peace [http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=62&Itemid=96 "History"]. ==Significant programs== ===The Fragile States Index=== The [[Failed States Index|Fragile States Index]] assesses the pressures experienced by nations based on social, economic, and political indicators such as demographic pressures, refugee flows, uneven economic development or severe economic decline, and human rights, among others.{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/fundforpeace/docs/cr-10-97-ca-conflictassessmentindicators-1105c/2 |title=Conflict Assessment Indicators Pocket Guide |publisher=Issuu.com |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=2012-07-16}} The "Failed States Index" debuted in 2005 with a limited assessment of approximately 75 countries; this was expanded to 146 countries in 2006, and then to 177 countries the following year.{{Cite web|url=http://fsi.fundforpeace.org/faq-01-how-many-countries-in-fsi|title=How Many Countries are Included in the Fragile States Index?|website=fsi.fundforpeace.org|access-date=2016-05-06}} South Sudan was added to the assessment in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://library.fundforpeace.org/fsi12-southsudan|title=An Inauspicious Welcome to South Sudan|website=library.fundforpeace.org|access-date=2016-05-06}} In 2014, The Fund for Peace announced that the ranking would be renamed "''Fragile'' States Index", claiming that the controversial term 'failed' had "[become] a distraction away from the point of the Index, which is to encourage discussions that support an increase in human security and improved livelihoods."{{Cite web|url=http://library.fundforpeace.org/blog-20140528-fsirenamed|title=Renaming the Failed States Index|website=library.fundforpeace.org|access-date=2016-05-06}} The Fragile States Index uses color-coded maps, tables, and a four level-ranking system ("Alert," "Warning," "Moderate," "Sustainable") to determine the current conditions and negative potential in the future. All four nations on high "Alert" are a part of the African continent: [[Somalia]], [[Sudan]], [[South Sudan]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. At the "Warning" level were many Latin American or former Soviet nations, including [[Moldova]], [[Russia]], [[Belarus]], [[Colombia]], [[Bolivia]], and [[Mexico]]. At "Moderate" were the [[United States]] and several European states, such as [[Latvia]], [[Poland]], [[Italy]], and [[Spain]]. Only a few nations, such as the Scandinavian countries, [[Iceland]], [[Ireland]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] were rated as "Sustainable."{{cite web|url=http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=fsi-grid2011 |title=The Failed States Index 2011 Interactive Grid |publisher=The Fund for Peace |date= |accessdate=2012-07-16}} The Fragile States Index is subject to criticism, in part, because it takes institutions and data to draw its conclusions, as opposed to the Human Development Index or other more telling signs. The FSI is checked against human analysis. ==== Governments' reactions to the FSI ==== * [[Mohamed ElBaradei|Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei]] called [[Egypt]]'s low-rank on the FSI "a disaster"{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/elbaradei-egypts-failed-state-designation-disaster|title=ElBaradei: Egypt's failed state designation 'a disaster'|accessdate=2012-08-17}} * U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton cites FSI research in State Department report to congress{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} * U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates uses FSI research in the 2010 Quadrennial Defense Review{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} ===UNLocK=== UNLocK links global information technologies with local social networks for the benefits of stakeholders. FFP conducts workshops in the conflict-affected countries of [[Liberia]], [[Uganda]], and [[Nigeria]], training local participants in the Conflict Assessment System Tool (CAST). They train others at the community level. Data collected from field reports by the participants are analyzed for signs of early-warning conflict. The aggregate data is privately disseminated back to the participants and used to resolve disputes, identify priority issues at the community level, and as a way to obtain more immediate early warning and conflict prevention information. While the recent elections in [[Nigeria]] were widely recognized as a major step forward in the difficult journey toward democracy, UNLocK Nigeria provided a ground-level view of challenges that remained, including incidents of ballot box snatching, vote-buying, abductions, and violence. This report focuses on the [[Niger Delta|Niger Delta Region]], with a particular emphasis on the [[Akwa Ibom State|Akwa Ibom]] and [[Rivers State|Rivers]] states.http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/library/cr-11-18-ul-unlocknigeria-1106a.pdf ===Threat convergence=== [[File:Lunapic 130894111190896 1.JPG|thumb|alt= Regional Analysis - Sindh Province, Pakistan|Demographic pressures differentiated regionally throughout Pakistan, pre-flood (left) and post-flood (right).]] The Center for the Study of Threat Convergence explores the linkages between fragile states, the proliferation of [[Weapons of Mass Destruction]], and [[terrorism]]. *'''The center aims to''':{{cite web|url=http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=tc-about |title=About Threat Convergence |publisher=The Fund for Peace |date= |accessdate=2012-07-16}} ** raise the profile of the challenges in vulnerable, fragile and ungoverned regions on the nonproliferation agenda; ** explore how these regions may serve as enabling environments for nuclear terrorism; ** promote more coherent and strategic policy approaches to nuclear terrorism and illicit nuclear trafficking. *'''Recently Published Reports''': ** [http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=cr-11-16-tc North Korean WMD Trading Relationships] ** [http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=ttcvr1104 Proliferation of Conventional Weapons] ** [http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=cr-11-01-tc Threat Convergence in Pakistan] CSTC performs ground research in the [[Black Sea]]/[[South Caucasus|South Caucasus region]], the [[Triple Frontier|Tri-border area of Latin American]], [[East Africa|East]] and the [[Horn of Africa]], and [[Southeast Asia]]. It partners with regional and sub regional organizations like [[NATO]], the [[European Union|EU]], and [[african union|the African Union]]. The Center for the Study of Threat Convergence is funded by the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]], the [[Ford Foundation]], and the [[Ploughshares Fund]]. ===Business and FFP=== Created in 1997, the '''Human Rights and Business Roundtable''' brings together businesses and human rights organizations to ensure compliance with international standards, particularly in regard to the conduct of security forces in and around industrial operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.fundforpeace.org/global/?q=program-hrbrt |title=Human Rights and Business Roundtable |publisher=The Fund for Peace |date= |accessdate=2012-07-16}} It recognizes the challenges faced, particularly in the extractive industries, in balancing human rights and security. FFP works with various private companies in the oil, mining, agribusiness, renewable energy, and infrastructure sectors in both stable and conflict zones around the world. The '''Sustainable Development & Security''' program supports companies in their development of human rights and security policies, conflict and human rights assessments, community relations and stakeholder engagement, and monitoring and reporting mechanisms.{{Cite web|url=http://sds.fundforpeace.org/sds|title=Sustainable Development & Security {{!}} The Fund for Peace|website=sds.fundforpeace.org|access-date=2016-05-06}} FFP is a long-standing civil society participant of the [[Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights|Voluntary Principles on Security & Human Rights]] initiative, and currently serves on the initiative's Steering Committee and Board of Directors. ===CAST=== For [[Conflict analysis|conflict assessment]], the Fund for Peace utilizes the Conflict Assessment System Tool (CAST). CAST was created in 1996 as a system of locating and analyzing potential conflicts in [[failed states]]. It works by incorporating "theoretical rationale, a conceptual framework, quantitative and qualitative indicators...and a rating system for trend analysis.{{cite web|url=http://www.fundforpeace.org/cast/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=13&Itemid=27 |title=Conflict Assessment System Tool - About CAST |publisher=The Fund for Peace |date= |accessdate=2012-07-16}} " However, CAST may be criticized for putting too much emphasis on technology and equations, and not enough on the human analysis.Moore, Jennifer [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=241795 "From Nation State to Failed State"], Columbia Human Rights Law Review, 1999. Furthermore, CAST is a tool that remains static, despite the specific conflict at hand. Each case is unique, and CAST does not have the mathematical ability to assess the uniqueness and specific needs of varying failed states.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=107&Itemid=145], The Fund for Peace, CAST. FFP maintains relationships with the [[United States Marine Corps]] and the [[South Korea]]n government, among others. ==Past programs== ===Genocide prevention=== As the Fund for Peace works in regions prone to genocide, the organization developed a relationship with the [https://www.un.org/en/preventgenocide/adviser/index.shtml Office of the Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide].United Nations [https://www.un.org/en/preventgenocide/adviser/index.shtml "Office of the Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide Mission Statement"] UN Official Website. The Special Adviser played a role in researching and delivering information to aid the Special Adviser in his responsibilities. The Special Adviser and the Fund for Peace were involved in researching human rights violations, sharing information and giving warnings to the Secretary General and the Security Council on matters of genocide, and making recommendations on courses of action.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=444&Itemid=892], The Fund for Peace, Genocide Prevention. ===Peace and Stability Operations Project=== Originally called the Regional Responses to Internal War Project, the program looks to shed light on regional organizations and their "political will" to maintain peaceful relations. The Peace and Stability Operations Project also serves to form relationships with actors in other sectors, such as scholars, research institutions, journalists, and experts. The Fund for Peace believes that, through these extended relationships, the international community can work together to maintain peace in typically violent areas. The Fund for Peace has been successful in advancing the international dialogue on peacekeeping by holding public meetings with international representatives, performing research missions in over thirty-five countries, and holding workshops. By collaborating with actors in other sectors, the Fund for Peace is able to gather the ideas and opinions of other experts and publish them in their issues of [http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=125&Itemid=173 Reality Check: Diverse Voices on Internal Conflict].[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=208&Itemid=257], The Fund for Peace, Peace and Stability Operations Project. ===United States foreign policy=== The second initiative is the Use and Purpose of American Power. The goal of this initiative is to promote ongoing dialogue and debate on the role of the United States in the international arena. It does so by asking four questions: * What are our interests and values as we act in the world? * What are the specific goals we should set and the things we should do? * What tools do we use to achieve these? * How as Americans do we influence events as they so obviously affect us?[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=309&Itemid=566], the Fund for Peace, Use and Purpose of American Power. The Use and Purpose of American Power also has three main components. The first is the National Dialogue forums. In 2008 and 2009, the Fund for Peace partnered up with local organizations, such as chambers of commerce and universities, across the country and organized "'traveling town halls.'" The purpose of these were to discuss topics relating to the presidential election, and the condition of the United States and its population. The format of the forums were designed to encourage participation and dialogue on behalf of Americans to actively and critically think about their role, their country's condition, and the government's responsibility. Throughout two years, the National Dialogue forums took place in Pennsylvania, Ohio, New Mexico, Alabama, Idaho, Florida, and California.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=328&Itemid=563], The Fund for Peace, National Dialogue Forums. The second component is the American Conversation. While the National Dialogue forums were designed to spark interest and discussion, the purpose of the American Conversation is an online discussion hosted by [https://groups.google.com/group/american-conversation?hl=en Google Groups] to continue conversations that began at the National Dialogue forums. The American Conversation is an effort by the Fund for Peace to encourage ongoing critical thinking in the minds of Americans and their communities.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=331&Itemid=879], The Fund for Peace, American Conversation. The third component of the Use and Purpose of American Power is the Final Report. The Final Report is a summary of the National Dialogue forums and the ideas and concepts presented at the forums. The Final Report, titled [http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/images/pdf/use_and_purpose_of_american_power_final_report.pdf The Use and Purpose of American Power in the 21st Century] highlights five main points: * "Economic security is vital to American national security; but America’s structural economic problems prevent it from operating from a position of strength in the world." * "National leaders should first ‘take care of their own’ because of the gravity of the economic challenges; however, America’s welfare is also closely tied to the world economy." * "Nation-building and democracy-building projects are a mission impossible; still, the U.S. should promote good governance, human rights, and equitable development." * "Terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) are lesser threats than America’s economic problems." * "U.S. leaders’ inability to adapt to new global realities poses the greatest challenge to America’s standing in the world."[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=448&Itemid=897], The Fund for Peace, Final Report. The Fund for Peace's efforts in United States foreign policy is based on the fear of "spillover" and the influence and multiplication of failed states.Mallaby, Sebastian [http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/57800/sebastian-mallaby/the-reluctant-imperialist-terrorism-failed-states-and-the-case-f "The Reluctant Imperialist"], Foreign Affairs, 2002. The National Dialogue forums were sponsored by the Fund for Peace. The Final Report was funded by the [[Ford Foundation]].[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=448&Itemid=897], The Fund for Peace, Funding. ===Human rights=== Another initiative to promote human rights is the Globalization and Human Rights Series. This consists of publications dedicated to discussing pertinent topics relating to human rights, the impact of failing states, and corruption. Four issues have been published since 2005 in an effort to continue to educate the industries and the public on the harmful effects of failing governments, and the need for the recognition of, and commitment to, human rights.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=112&Itemid=156], The Fund for Peace, Globalization and Human Rights Series. Furthermore, the Fund for Peace is a supporter of the [[Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights]], which guides businesses who voluntarily participate on how to align their security practices with human rights considerations.[http://www.voluntaryprinciples.org/ "Voluntary Principles"] The Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights. The [[Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights|Voluntary Principles]] are important because of the potentially harmful impacts security practices can have when operating in a failed state or conflict zone, but also because the international community is putting increasing emphasis on the rights of individuals.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=438&Itemid=601], The Fund for Peace, Civil Society and Human Rights. ==Other collaboration== The Fund for Peace does not limit its partnerships to select sectors. The organization has collaborated with [[Georgetown University]]'s Center for Peace and Security Studies and the [[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute]]. Together, the three institutions developed a [http://www.press.georgetown.edu/book/georgetown/peace-operations thesis on the increased participation of regional organizations] and their member states in promoting peacekeeping.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=209&Itemid=248], The Fund for Peace, ''Peace Operations: Trends, Progress, and Prospects'' The Fund for Peace partnered with the [[Centre for International Governance Innovation]] in 2007. From September 4–6, thirty participants from varying Middle Eastern countries, as well as Australia, the United States, and Canada, met in Istanbul, Turkey. The participants came from academia, international organizations, the Arab League, the United Nations, governments, and human rights organizations. The representatives were faced with the task of determining what steps should be taken to efficiently protect civilians. The conference promoted a sense of international unity by asking the representatives to leave aside their political ideologies and keep the welfare of human beings as their priority. The conference ended with the unanimous support of [[International Humanitarian Law]] and the [http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/images/pdf/the%20bosphorous%20consensus%20final%2011.07.07.pdf Bosphorous Consensus].[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=192&Itemid=252], The Fund for Peace, the Middle East. The Fund for Peace has also partnered with Logos Technologies, the [[United States Institute of Peace]], the [[PKSOI|United States Peacekeeping and Stability Operations Institute]], the [[Office of the Coordinator for Reconstruction and Stabilization|U.S. State Department Office of the Coordinator for Stabilization and Reconstruction]], and the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] to create a metrics framework for peacekeeping. The project includes concepts from the book ''The Quest for Viable Peace'' with the theoretical approach of the Fund for Peace's CAST methodology. The organizations involved are interested in helping governments determine the outcome of Stabilization and Reconstruction Operations.[http://www.fundforpeace.org/web/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=191&Itemid=253], The Fund for Peace, Metrics for Stability. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://fundforpeace.org/ Official website] [[Category:Peace and conflict studies]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Think tanks based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1957]]
